1.content:
Ryan stared out the window of the Arena with bitterness in his eyes. This was the first time he had been in the Grand Arena, but he had been battle-hardened from months in the pit fights. Every day served as a new reminder that his family counted on him to save them. His wife didn't even know the danger she was in yet. And his uncle...
He suppressed the hatred he felt at the thought of Kane. It was Kane who had dragged him broken and bleeding across the desert to simply sell him into fighting, something he had been trying to escape for years.
"Ryan, are you all right?" Sarah asked from the top bunk. She watched him with a sad expression. Her brother would never have recognized him, if he were still alive. Ryan had once been a happy little boy, but things had changed too much since then.
"Not yet. Soon, though." he responded quietly. "Soon."

Early morning found Siph and Ressek sitting on the windowsill, welcoming the dawn's weak golden light. Ressek's long tail swished across the floor, occasionally knocking one of its bony nodules against the stone walls.
"I wanna win, Rethik. I wanna be da champion oth da Arena." Siph had yet to master common speech, and spoke with a lisp.
"You wish for the chance to face Calarith? You were always weird, Siph, but I never believed you were insane." Ressek sighed, his forked reptillian tongue flickering in the air. "And now I'm in the mess with you. Though I relish the chance to kick Krath around, I don't want to be here."
Siph patted his friend. "I know, Rethik. I'm thorry."

David Talis watched his son sleep from the doorway. Dawn was breaking, but John could sleep through almost anything. It almost brought a tear to the lycanthrope's eye, for he had thought that he would never see his son again, let alone anyone. But now they were to be in the same Arena, fighting each other.
John's eyes opened and he watched his father for a moment. The man wasn't young anymore, but still had a youthful strength.
"You shouldn't have come." David said softly. "I want you to get out of here, no matter what."
"I know you do. But I can't." John hesitated. "Mother thinks you're dead. She's sad and scared to believe otherwise."
"I can understand that. But I promise, we'll get out."
John gave a small smile to his father and then climbed out of his bunk to prepare for what may be his longest day yet.

Raven gnawed on the bars of his cage, for lack of anything else to do. He may have been the most violent of all the competitors, and they wouldn't allow him a roommate, for fear of him eating them before the fights. He stiffened at the sound of someone coming down the stairs. He was almost like a puppy, growing excited at the prospect of visitors.
Elise stopped just outside of the sturdy metal cage, studying the dragonette carefully. Finally, she spoke.
"This is all your fault. If you had just left me alone, everything would have been fine." she spat the words like venom, and Raven's smile broadened. He let out a strange noise, something like a squawk and an eagle's cry.
She growled at him. "You will pay soon, little dragon." Then she turned and headed back up the stairs.

Marr floated out of his room, stretching his arms before the start of competition. Dark green mosses and weeds trailed from his three right claws, and left sickle. Both his claws and sickle were the only solid points on his form. They were a dark greyish-brown, the color of muddy bones, which in fact, they were.
"Come back here, fog-slime!"
Marr slowly turned, fixing his slanted red eyes on the brute behind him.
our time is not yet, krath, the wraith said. Its voice, if the sound could be called that, was little more than a whisper, and often confused for a breeze than communication.
"Don't give me that, fog-slime. I kill you now, if I could." With an angry grunt, Krath stomped off down the hall in the opposite direction, his long tail swishing menacinly behind.
ha, the fool. he can't hope to kill me. Marr chuckled, echoing the sibiliant sound through the long hallways of the Arena.

Tyger practiced another thrust, imagining Ryan's head in place of the wooden target. She didn't like the warrior, and aimed to kill him. She started at the sound of Shalar's voice.
"You are quick." He stated simply. "I'm sure that if Ryan's death is at your hands, it will be slow and painful, though."
He stared solemnly at his bladed claws. "I only wish that Reivus' death could be avenged in the same manner." He paused, and glanced up at Tyger, his long head-blade swinging in line with her throat. "Why do you hate him, Tyger?"
She glared at the bladed warrior. "He is my enemy. We disagree on certain issues. Also, he reminds me of the man who killed the rest of my clan. Besides," she added, smirking. "He's Harac's grandson."
Shalar stared hard at her, then laughed. "And he is the man who killed Reivus' murderer, Tyger. By all rights, I should thank him. You ought to as well."
She shrugged and pushed his head-blade away from her, turning his head. "I have no reason to thank him, unlike you. The man who killed my clan was also one of the last. Like Ryan, he was a Catalyst."
"Then he was a fool. Ryan is no such thing, Tyger. And he shouldn't be your target. After all," Shalar stated, "he's trying to do what you never could- save his family."
She glared at him, trying to find words. Finally, she managed to cool herself down. "Perhaps. But you are wrong. He is a Catalyst, and I don't envy you discovering that when you fight." With that, she pushed past him and into the halls. The fights would begin soon, and she would not miss it.

Calarith gazed in wonder as the dawn sun rose above the Arena's walls. "It's glorious, isn't it?" he asked. The Arena's master nodded silently, still awed by the presence of the massive dragon. "From all parts, they come. And for what end? To earn a chance to fight me." The dragon sighed happily, a tongue of fire flickering from his nostrils and mouth. "Glorious..."
The Arena's master simply nodded again. "If you'll excuse me, Calarith, I must start the competitions. I trust you will come to watch?"
This time it was the dragon's turn to nod. "I will see them prove themselves, or die trying."
1.title: Prologue

11.content:
Calarith spread his large, fan-like wings and leapt from the outside wall of the Arena. Swooping low, he sped over the dirt floor of the battleground, barely missing the twenty-foot wall that kept the fighters in their place as he reached the opposite end of the Arena. Already, people were starting to filter in, getting early seats for the day's bouts.
The great dragon shook his head, causing the tassels on his headfins to swish back and forth. Without warning, a gout of fire shot into the sky- the current Champion roaring his defiance to the would-be challengers. He knew that deep below, in the bowls of the great Arena, his challenge would be echoing through the stone hallways and passages, ringing in the ears of the combatants.
Smiling broadly, Calarith landed on the opposite wall, on a broad terrace made for the wealthiest of observers. His sharp eyes noted shadows behind the Arena's entrances.
It will begin soon, Calarith thought. On another terrace, much closer to the Arena's floor, the Arena master stood, preparing to begin the fighting.
11.title: The Watcher

111.content:
Ryan makes Krath look even clumsier, Calarith mused as Ryan sliced another bloody ribbon across Krath's chest with his sword. The thick rough skin gave reluctantly against Ryan's blade, but his strength and skill were more than enough to persevere.
Krath roared in pain and anger, lashing out with his long tail to try and bring Ryan to the ground. The attempt failed horribly, Ryan deftly leaping over the swiping tail and scoring another long gash as it passed below him.
Then Krath saw his chance. With the fastest movement he could muster, he backhanded Ryan, his claws and wrist blades digging into the warrior's flesh.
Ryan flew backwards, hitting the ground several feet away. Blood leaked from the sharp gouges in his side and chest.
111.title: Backhanded!

113.content:
Elise was lead out. Her eyes narrowed as she spotted Ressek. His skin was a golden brown, and he was scowling fiercely.
Elise was handed a sword. She looked at it doubtfully. No magic anywhere in the dull blade.
She murmered some words. They got stronger and stronger, flowing into the weapon like oil in a pond. Soon the blade was shining brightly. Elise muttered a shield spell in case she was called off for starting before the fight was declared.
Ressek was also handed a sword. It was of broad steel, he noted, with the plain pommel used by the peasants in tavern brawls. He clenched his teeth and threw away the sword. I fight with my body, not with steel.
The Arena master dropped a red cloth, signifying the start of battle.
The two figures advanced. Elise's lips seemed to be mouthing something. Ressek ignored it. What good were prayers in a field of hell?
He was knocked down with the force of the blow. He hit the sand with such force that heis sword struck the ground and stayed upright, vibrating.
Quick as lightning Ressek scrambled up, lashing out with his long tail. The bony nodules whipped into Elise's head, sending her reeling. Elise swiftly wheeled to the right, cutting Ressek's arm.
He cried out in pain. It was not an ordinary wound. He could feel it vibrating with magic. Ressek might not have been a mage, but he could detect magic.
113.title: Magic's Heart

choices: Ressek smashes a blow to her pressure point, killing her
Ressek demands her surrender as she is clearly beaten.
1131.content: Elise advanced her sword raised certain the saurian would prove no threat as she saw his strength drain from the magic in his wound. She briefly muttered another spell to make the blade grow even stronger and then lifted above the shrinking lizard eager for an easy kill, she swung the glowing blade down at his unprotected head braced herself for impact and fell on the floor, in the instant before the blade connected the lizard had moved. Suddenly an incredible blow crashed against her shield wall breaking her concentration and causing the wall to unravel, then the lizard was on her, he pushed his scaled finger into the point just behind her ear and she felt excruciating pain spill through her body.
1131.title: Victory for Ressek?

choices: Calarith leaves the Arena for other matters
11312.content:
"Give up, Elise. This fight is over- I have no intention of killing you."
Elise glared flaming razors at Ressek. "As you killed Raven? As you took away my one goal in life? As you destroyed my purpose?" She spat, still twisted in Ressek's grip. "Kill me. End this purposeless existence."
"Surrender, fool. I do not wish to kill you."
"And I wish to be killed, lizard! Dammit, Ressek, destroy me! My life is over, my road at an end!"
A war raged inside Ressek. It would be easy to grant Elise's screaming requests, but that was not who he was. Seek your death elsewhere, Elise, the martial artist thought, and struck an entirely different point on her body. A pained squeak escaped her as she crumpled to the ground, unconcious.

"Look at that, Warden. A fighter who does not wish to kill. This may be an interesting tournament after all."
"Interesting, yes," the Arena master replied, scowling at Ressek, "but not what will satisfy the crowd. They want blood, and it will be up to me to make sure that they get it. Peli, come here."
A short, stocky woman came forward, bearing a piece of parchment with the names of the competitors. "Yes, Jared?"
"I told you before- never call me by that name."
"Of course, Arena master."
"Make sure Ressek's next fight is with Raven." Turning back to Calarith, the stout master of the Arena grinned. "If they won't see the blood of those Ressek fights, they will see his."
Calarith watched as they exited the terrace, making whatever preparations were necessary for the next fight, and decided he did not like the manipulative little man who ran his battlegrounds. True, the Arena was a creation he enjoyed, very much, but its owner was truly foul in Calarith's eyes. "Aumer have mercy on your soul, Jared, when he claims you at last."
11312.title: "Surrender, Fool"

113121.content:
Roughly ninety miles east of the Arena lay the city of Port Cannon, the southernmost known coastal city, and well south of the Five Kingdoms. It was here that Calarith flew, his wings carrying him over the scorching desert far quicker than any earth-bound traveler could hope to match. A trip that would take Arena supply caravans three days or more took Calarith only half a day. And so, shortly after noon, the massive dragon landed outside the city, scanning the low rooftops for the person he was supposed to meet.

"You say Michael Ryan's captor left here a day ago?"
The cloaked figure nodded. Sandy yellow robes hid most of his features, but the human was still of a distinguished build, and besides, only a few kept the hoods of their robes up in desert heat, even if the cool breeze of the ocean were upon them.
"Kane left in a sloop yesterday morning, headed out north. He was very skittish, and barely talked to anyone."
"Daskir, remove that silly hood. There's no reason to hide your scars from me."
Hesitant to obey the dragon, but more hesitant to do otherwise, the man removed his hood.
Even after all this time, such atrocities between humans amaze me, Calarith thought blandly. The left side of the man's face was normal, though slightly wrinkled with age, but the left side was a thick mass of scarred tissue. His right eye was a sickly yellow, his cheekbones all but revealed under a very thin layer of puckered scars. His jaw was pitted with small depressions, and near the joint of it was a deep pit nearly an inch across. Another legacy of the 18-year war Harac had waged on the Five Kingdoms.
"Now that you have marveled at my deformities, Calarith, may I conceal them again? Such gawking is unbecoming of a dragon."
"Yes, of course, Daskir. I thank you for your information on Kane. Ryan will owe me a favor for this, and if it is him I fight in the final match, such information will throw him off-balance. I do not fear fighting a Catalyst, but there is always the chance that I may lose."
"Of course, Calarith. Speed of Aumer be with you," the scarred veteran said, turning.
"And His strength with you, Daskir," Calarith replied. Turning, the dragon left the edge of the city, winging his way back towards the Arena. With luck, he could still catch the last fight of the day.
113121.title: Port Cannon

115.content:
Raven entered the Arena. Prepared to take anyone on. Jonathan entered casually. Seeing no threat.
" BEGIN " the master shouted
Raven immediately attack Jonathan but missed. Jonathan knocked Raven far across the arena.Raven looked unconcsious. Jonathan went towards him....big mistake...
" AHHHHH " someone yelled as he leapt out from behind Raven and immediately killed Jonathan.
" DISQUALIFICATION " the master yelled.
The shadowy figure disappeared. Because of his stunt Raven was disqualified and killed...Next battle...
115.title: Raven vs. Jonathan WHAT?! DISQUALIFICATION!

1151.content:
David woke with a start. "Johnathan, my son...Rediculous!" He shook his head- the fights had yet to begin. Quickly he sat up and looked around. On all the Arena's terraces above him, people were filtering in for the start of battle. He smiled. His son was still alive- the whole chaotic dream had been just that.

Because Raven was such a beast, he could not be released prior to the start of competition. The Arena master stood on his terrace, the one closest to the battlegrounds. In his hand, he held a blood red cloth. "Today begins the start of a noble ascension. One of the warriors you will see today will climb to the pinnacle of success, and challenge the Champion, the great dragon Calarith."
The dragon, perched high above the Arena's bowl, on the outer walls, roared with approval and shot a gout of flame into the air.
"When this cloth drops, the battle is joined. Have at it, fighters!" whereupon he released the cloth. Iron gates were drawn back from Raven's cell, and he raced into the morning light, hungry for blood.
1151.title: The start of battle

12.content: Shalar watched Tyger as she stormed off down the hallways, reflecting that perhaps it had been a bad idea to needle her as he had. Play with fire, you'll get burned...you had it coming, Tyger. He shook his head to clear out the thoughts, and walked slowly down the steps to where the fighting rosters were posted. His bladed foot-claws make a clicking sound as they hit the cold stone floor. I must learn to walk quieter, he told himself. Several others were already running through their rosters, but Shalar managed to see who he was fighting. His claws clicked together with anticipation.
12.title: Bladed Bout

122.content:
"How ironic," Shalar chuckled. With out another word, he walked towards the staging areas.

Two fights had already taken place before it was his turn. In spots, blood splattered the ground, turning the dirt a deep red-brown.
How very encouraging, Shalar thought.
Where his elbows ended, not one but two forearms grew, giving him four clawed hands to bear against his enemies. With talon-like blades for toes and fingers, he was confident that he could deflect Tyger's twin dirks. He smiled grimly.
"Anger or no, Tyger, I will fight and win. Nothing can stop me until I face David Talis. When he dies at my hands, I can rest."
On these words, the stone door of the Arena opened, and he blinked in the bright morning light. "And then it begins," he muttered...
122.title: "And then it begins..."

1221.content:
Tyger came at him out of the sun, the only clue of her attack a slight glitter from one of her dirks. She's careful, she holds the blades straight so they reflect little light at me... But Shalar's sharp eyes had caught the faint glitter, and he dove to the right, rolled, and stood, bringing his four arms up in a double cross over his chest. Weak golden light spattered the ground, reflecting from his bronze clawblades.
"Wily one, aren't you? No matter, Shalar. Your insults this morning will be paid in blood." Tyger shot at him again, charging in low with both dirks. Involuntarily, Shalar took a step back. His smooth white hide felt the cold stones of the Arena walls. Damn, my back against the wall already. She'll kill me if I stay here... But with only forwards to go, he would have to break past Tyger to evade her.
As she neared him, he crouched low on his powerful legs, and leapt into the air, aiming over Tyger's head...
1221.title: Leap of Faith

12211.content:
As Shalar came down behind her, Tyger lashed out with her tail in an attempt to trip him. He blocked it with his own tail, and the wickedly sharp blade on it ripped blood and flesh from her as it deflected the attack.
"Damn you, Shalar!" she hissed.
He turned, opening the long, lobster-like claws on his left arms, practically daring her to attack.
"The damned are the ones who live longest, Tyger. Haven't you noticed?" Tyger turned to face him, bringing her dirks up. "After all, look how long Ryan has lived, so damned by his enemies."
Tyger leapt at him, but Shalar caught her right arm in his open claws, throwing her to the side. He pivoted as she flew past, and the blade-hook on his elbow scored a long bloody furrow down her ribs.
Once wounded, Tyger became enraged. But twice wounded, she became cautious. One hit I might put down to luck. But two is too many. I must be careful, or he'll have me dead on the ground soon.
Shalar noted how she withdrew after his last blow. She's becoming cautious- I've overplayed myself. The fight will be that much harder, now.
For Shalar, two arms became four at the elbows, and he crossed all four in a guarding position. His eyes flickered gold, his equivalent of blinking. "Shall we start again?" he asked Tyger.
12211.title: First blood

choices: Tyger goes for her other dirk
122112.content:
"Shut up, Shalar," Tyger hissed. She took a couple steps back, and tenderly probed her wounded ribs. Only a shallow slice. Hurts like hell, but won't keep me from fighting.
In another mighty leap, Shalar landed beside her. Quick as lightning, they locked blades, Tyger barely managing to block his four sets of claws. However, she could do little or nothing about his long head-blade. Its hooked tip ripped another gouge, this time across her forehead. Blood streaming down into her eyes, she flung him back.
Shalar stumbled a bit, but caught himself with his tail, and looked back. Tyger no longer stood before him, and as he looked up, he caught her bony foot square in the face. Overbalanced, he fell to the ground, lashing out blindly with his left arms, claws raking the air. A hiss from Tyger and a tug at the tips of his blades told him the slash had been successful, but at a price. Hot amber blood ran down his arms, a deep slice suddenly evident in his upper arm.
A throbbing ache began in his injured arm, but he pushed it aside.
"Well done, Tyger. You have blooded me after all."
"After all!?!" Tyger shrieked. "You calm, silent son of a bitch! Damn you, you're as bad as Ryan at times!" She was breathing heavily, but mastered her anger, pushed it down. No, I can't let him rile me! To do so is to blind myself and invite death at those claws. Tyger chuckled. Not that he'd have the heart to finish me, but why take chances? I won't fall so easily.
After a few seconds more, and without any further talk, they clashed again. The crowd roared with approval, these two inhuman combatants hacking and clawing at eachother. A loud clang resounded through the stands and bowl of the Arena, and a glint of metal flew through the air, flashing brightly in the mid-morning light. One of Tyger's dirks, caught and tossed away in Shalar's claws. It buried itself in the dirt some yards away.
122112.title: Amber Blood and Lost Dirks

choices: Shalar doesn't feel her behind him...
1221121.content:
Knowing she had no chance against his four arms with a single dirk, Tyger slowly circles Shalar. Nice try, little one thinks Shalar, as he moves in an opposite circle, cutting off her indirect route to her blade. "You're going to have to think of something better than that," he calls to her. To his surprise, she rushes right at him, flying dirk first straight for his head. In an effort to avoid getting impaled by her mad dash, he throws his four arms infront of his face, simultaneously throwing himself down and lashing blindly with his tail blade.
Feeling nothing, Shalar opens his arms and sees...
an empty arena. Where are you, little one?
1221121.title: Kamikaze?

1221122.content:
Tyger brought up her single dirk, knowing she was overmatched at least four-to-one. Four arms with blades, to my one dirk. His tail has a blade, as does his head, elbows...Damn! I can't fight like this! As they were about to clash again, Tyger threw herself skyward. In a last-second effort, Shalar whipped his lower-left arm up, reaching out to draw yet another slash in her tail. But Tyger ignored the pain and flew high. Now I have the advantage. Time to use it... She swooped at Shalar, shooting past him to draw a thick amber line on his side, inflicting another wound on the solid creature. Shalar hissed in pain, but stood resolutely in the middle of the Arena's grounds, making no move for cover.
"Cat and mouse, Tyger. You're reaching the end of your rope, I can tell."
She did not bother to respond, but swooped at him again. As she flew by, all four arms lashed out, locking their claws onto her blade arm and waist. Roughly, she was thrown into the ground, tumbling a few times before her momentum carried her into the stone walls of the Arena's border. Everyone in the audience could hear the thump she made as she hit.
1221122.title: Grounded

choices: A short rest in the Barracks
A quick lunch in the Mess Hall
12211221.content:
Slowly, Tyger rose to her feet, shaking off diziness. "Damn you, Shalar. I didn't want to kill you. Even the infuriating calmness didn't matter. But you've stepped squarely into Ryan's place, and now you too must die."
Shalar just laughed. "Tyger, you are strong, but you haven't got enough left to kill me. Defeat me, perhaps, but not kill me." He began walking slowly towards the gargoyle.
Tyger watched him come, closer and closer until they were less than a yard apart- more than enough for a lunge, a shot at his heart. Shalar's eyes flashed gold again as he "blinked," silently evaluating Tyger. He saw her eyes seeking out a weakness, and with a lunge forward, he backhanded her into the wall. Already dizzy from the first collision, she collapsed with a short, anguished cry, and lay still.

Shalar turned from the unconcious gargoyle and walked swiftly from the Arena. How sad that it ends this way. I walk from the field more her enemy than I woke as, this morning.
Behind him, the stone doors of the Arena slid shut.
12211221.title: Backhanded to Victory

122112211.content:
Shalar was lying on his back, staring at the wooden beams of the ceiling, when Tyger came in. Without a word, she collapsed onto her bunk, the lower one. After a moment, she spoke.
"I'm sorry, Shalar. You're not my enemy, and I don't want to kill you."
Though she could not see it, Shalar smiled. "I know, Tyger. You're mad at Ryan, not me."
"Do you know what it's like to see family killed in front of you? To see them slaughtered before your eyes?"
"Yes. Reivus was my brother, in a mercinary company. He was killed in action twenty feet from me as the company was gaining victory."
Neither said anything more until an Arena orderly came to fetch Shalar for his next match.
122112211.title: Reivus' history

1221122111.content:
The sun was reaching its peak when Shalar took the field. Opposite him, Elise stood. Her long white robes were half-scorched from a previous fight, but she looked none the worse for the wear.
"Well, this day just gets better and better. First that damn dragonet, and now a walking fishhook." Elise spat on the ground with disgust. After besting her longtime enemy, Raven, she was full of contempt for non-humans. Shalar wasn't sure if it was because of Raven's survival, or because now that she had defeated him, she was a woman without a goal, a shell of her former determined self.
Either way, she's empty. I should take great care not to anger her, or her revenge will be long and slow.
The Arena master, for the fifth time that day, dropped the red flag that signaled the fights. Elise leapt back as Shalar's blades sliced the air she had been occupying a second ago. Tendrils of black fire snaked from her palms, but Shalar's ruddy gold blades deflected the soul-scorching flames.
"You're a shell of who you were, Elise. Raven's defeat isn't enough for you, is it?"
"He ruined my childhood, Shalar!" she spat. "He destroyed my life, and he lives yet! I have faced and defeated him, but he still lives!"
His claws still held in a double guard across his chest, he stood openly in the center of the Arena. "You're worried that he'll come back, aren't you? That he'll rise up from the ranks and face you again."
"Wouldn't you feel the same, if Harac still lived? You think you would be satisfied to know that you've bested him if he still were alive?" She raised her arms muttering softly. Brilliant blue lightning gathered in a wide circle around her, seeping up from the ground. "You're pathetic, Shalar. The mediocre warrior, out to avenge his dead brother." Her eyes flared, and with them, the lightning flashed up around her in a column fifty feet high. The spectators closest to her side of the Arena backed away for fear of shock. "Well I lost far more than you, Shalar. And now I will teach you the pain of that loss."
Dammit! She could float ten feet above the ground, just out of reach, and win this fight as easily. Now I know why Reiver never liked mages...
1221122111.title: Shalar vs Elise

choices: Elise attacks with her half-finished spell
12211221111.content:
Shalar set his turtle-like jaw, glaring hard at the spell of lightning Elise was weaving. If I don't do something, and do it now, I'm barbeque. He spread his claws wide, lowering his guard, and charged the tower of electricity. His long legs pumped steadily, flying over the ground in long strides. I'm dead if I wait, and dead if I touch that lightning. There's got to be a way around it...

Elise's eyes narrowed as she saw Shalar charge her spell. "It's too late, Shalar. You'll never touch me until I'm ready for you," she muttered. But at the last second, when it seemed like he would run straight into the spell, he turned aside. His long gait took him to the Arena's twenty-foot stone walls in two more steps. With a mighty leap, he latched onto the walls, and began scaling them swiftly. His four arms heaved him upwards to the top of the wall, and by now Elise was beginning to get worried. What is he up to? Then she realized- her spell's power was weakest at the top! He could leap into it at perhaps the thirty-foot mark from there, and break through!
She tried to pull more power to her protective column, but it was too late. With a blinding flash, Shalar broke through, lightning trailing from his many blades. Unhurt, he landed at her feet.
"The pain of your loss is just beginning, Elise." His right claws gripped her by the shoulder and waist, and heaved her bodily into the sides of her own column. There was a briliant flash and Elise screamed in agony as the powerful bolts burned her skin wherever they touched, setting alight her robes in spots. In that instant, the whole column collapsed, tumbling inwards to bury Shalar under a cascade of lightning. He raised his claws over his head, covering as much of himself as he could, but the pain was still almost unbearable as the uncontrolled bolts scorched his back, lashing into him as they fell to earth and were drawn under.
Painfully, he stood, steam rising from the burns on his back. Elise stood, likewise smoking from her burns.
12211221111.title: Cascade of Lightning

choices: Elise brings the net down, crushing Shalar to emerge victorious
122112211111.content:
"If you thought," Elise said, gasping slightly, "that my own spell would put me out, you're sorely mistaken."
"You're stalling, Elise," Shalar said, but already, she had gained the time she needed.
"No longer, Fishhook." A cold blackness seemed to seep from her outstretched arm, enveloping Shalar like a fog. He was riveted to the spot, unable to move anything but his claws. They opened and closed in frustration, snapping at air.
"Take a good look at the light, Shalar. It's the last time you'll ever see it."
The inky fog became laced with the same blue lightning that had failed to protect Elise the first time, only now it formed a net around Shalar.
The crowd was silent, but on its feet, willing Elise to make the kill. And in the silence, a noise was rising. A low, tortured howling, as if all the pain of the earth were coming from the horizon to converge at the Arena. Gray flecks began to grow outside the net, leaking out like the dust of clay crushed in someone's hand. The net began to tighten, and the howling increased, until the Arena's stones were cracking from the sound.
"Ultimate pain, Shalar. To have your soul slowly stripped from your body, one bit at a time. Torn away like flesh from bone. Like my family was from me." Her eyes flashed. "That is pain, Shalar."
"We fall," Shalar gasped, the net draining him and crushing him at the same time, "to stand again." He sank to his knees, then heaved against the fog and lightning, pushing with every muscle in his body. Slowly, he rose to his feet, pushing the net back. His eyes fixed on Elise, and the gray flecks stopped gathering outside the net.
"I am standing once more, Elise. Pray that you can do the same when this is over."
122112211111.title: Soul Stripper

choices: Elise surrenders, and Shalar is allowed to leave the Arena
1221122111111.content:
Elise glared at him and pushed with all her might, trying to bring down the soul-stripping net, but with each moment, another fleck of gray was disappearing back into the black fog and Shalar grew stronger.
His large eyes glowed a brilliant gold- he was closing them. Head bowed, he repeated, "We fall so that we may stand again." With that, he shoved against the sides of the net, his claws slicing through the magic Elise was struggling with. He brought his head up, and the blade jutting forward from his head did likewise, tearing a gash in the fog and energy.
The howling stopped, becoming an anguished scream as the net shattered. Elise shielded her eyes as the fog evaporated in a brilliant flash, throwing electric shrapnel everywhere.
And in the middle of it all, Shalar stood, the ground around him blackened. Though he was gasping for breath, he was otherwise unhurt. His eyes stopped glowing and he fixed them hard on Elise, who lowered her arm from her face. Her eyes widened in shock.
"No...no, no, that's not possible! How did you-?" She was cut off as Shalar again reached out, grabbing her by the throat with his long claws.
"You've pushed yourself hard, mage. But your reserves are almost dry. Continue this fight and you won't live through your next one."
He threw her to the ground in the center of the Arena and walked away, stopping in front of the stone doors that led to the staging area, and away from the fight. With my back turned, she'll never get a better opportunity for a quick strike. I can only hope she'll end the fight now, without further battle.
1221122111111.title: "We fall so that we may stand again."

12211221111111.content:
Shalar couldn't see Elise rise wearily to her feet, nor the spell that she was quickly summoning to blast him with. But he read the mood of the audience and could feel the power gathering behind him. As it built up, he tensed himself.
"You're a fool, Shalar. You let mercy cloud your judgement, and now you will fall because of it."
As she released the spell, her trademark black fireball, Shalar pivoted. He backhanded the dark flames with his claws, turning the magic back at its source. Tendrils of fire leaked down his claws, burning his arms, but the bulk of the fireball shot back across the dusty grounds of the Arena. Elise stood silently, consigned to the fate she had given herself, and made no sound as the fireball blasted her back across the grounds and into the wall at the far side. She crumpled to the ground, broken and bleeding.
Shalar turned sadly from the sight, his tail dragging its hooked blade in the dirt as he entered the cold darkness of the staging halls, leaving the noon heat behind.
12211221111111.title: Rebound

choices: An orderly catches Shalar in the halls and informs him of his next bout
122112211111111.content:
"He's good, isn't he?" Calarith said. The Arena master standing next to him on the terrace simply nodded.
"It's noon. I must hunt now." With a mighty leap, Calarith shot out over the arena, his great saurian shape aweing the shallow people in the stands below him. As the champion, he was the only competitor allowed to leave the Arena on his own.

Shalar glanced up just as the stone door closed behind him, leaving but a glimpse of the Champion's shadow as it soared off beyond the bounds of the Arena.
"Must be lunchtime. I should eat now, and give myself time to settle the food."
A guard turned to him as he passed. "Talking to me, sir?" the guard asked.
"No, just going to the mess for some food. Warriors must eat, you know."
As Shalar entered the mess hall in the Arena's southern walls, he noticed an undercurrent of tension running through those present in the hall. We all came here with such different goals- some of revenge, some of escape, and some with mindless brutality. But now it's as if everyone hates everyone. He grabbed a tray of food and sat down on at one of the most empty tables. As he was about to start eating, however, he noticed someone behind him.
"That was a good fight, Shalar. I noticed you let her live as well."
Shalar shrugged, and motioned for Tyger to sit down next to him.
"Your blades resist magic, don't they?" she asked him.
"Yes. Yet one more thing that makes me different," Shalar said, then added, "like letting my competition live."
Tyger just laughed, then her eyes narrowed, as though remembering something. "What was that you said to Elise when you broke her spell? 'We fall so that we may stand again?'"
Shalar nodded. "It's not magic. Just something Reivus used to say to me when I knocked him down in our fights." He sighed. "We would often practice fighting at home, before he joined the mercenary company. But things fell apart even before that, when he ran into one of Harac's pet mages. After what he did to Reivus, my brother took his death very slowly."
"What did the mage do?"
"He used a strange sort of 'steel-spell' on Rievus- sliced a long gash over one eye. Like yours," he said, tracing one of his long claws down her face, over the long scar that ran over it. She pulled away, frowning.
"His vision wasn't too bad, but the pain must've been unbearable. He made that mage last for over a fortnight on just a few crumbs and tepid water." Shalar shuddered, remembering the torture sessions his brother had undertaken. "Perhaps that's another reason why I'm kind to my enemies. I never want to be so brutal."
Tyger shrugged. "There are many things which could be considered brutal. Torture is just one of them."
It was Shalar's turn to shrug. "It's all in the past. And when I fight the son of the man who killed him...that will be the time to decide what brutal is..."
Shalar rose from the table. But though he could leave his half-finished meal in the mess hall, his memories continued to follow him.
122112211111111.title: Rememberance

choices: Shalar stays for some more rest
1221122111111111.content:
Shalar was lying on his back, staring at the bunk above him, when he heard Tyger enter.
"Another lecture, Tyger?"
She stared hard at him. "My fight is in two minutes, Shalar. I'm just getting some equipment." She sighed and sat down beside him on the pallet. "I wouldn't call a friendly discussion in the mess hall a 'lecture,' either."
"I'm sorry. Some memories rub too deep, you must know that. Especially with your deep hatred of the Catalyst, Ryan." Shalar blinked, the brief phosphorescence reflecting off the stone walls of their room.
Tyger bowed her head. "That's true. Now," she said, standing, "I have a match to win." She turned and left the room, her final words echoing back from the corridors. "You might as well come and watch- your next match is just after it."
1221122111111111.title: More Reflections

12211221111111111.content:
Shalar lay there a moment longer, wondering if he would be forced to dredge up memories he'd rather forget whenever Tyger was around. Some spend far too much time in the past. Tyger, your quest for vengeance isn't going to satisfy you now. Just as it failed Elise an hour ago. With a sigh, he rose and made his way to the terrace reserved for the Arena combatants to view the matches.

The Arena master was by now tired of his duties, and did not announce a long and glorious battle. He merely introduced the fighters, then dropped the red cloth. Below him, in the Arena's bowl, Tyger and Marr closed in on each other.
Marr's weakness is his eyes, Tyger. Go for them with one dirk, block with the other, Shalar urged silently.
12211221111111111.title: Reserved Judgement

choices: Tyger gets up and attacks again
122112211111111111.content:
Tyger went straight at Marr, throwing her whole being into the attack. But it was all for nothing, as Marr simply floated higher and let Tyger's fury pass through his lower half, well out of reach of his glowing red eyes.
As Tyger passed through him, she planted her right foot, heaving herself into the air behind the bog wraith's back. Slowly, too slowly, the wraith turned to find her hovering at face level, her large wings beating the air every few seconds. He slashed at her with his sickle arm, but she blocked the bone blade easily and wheeled inside his guard, driving her other dirk straight into his left eye.
The scream of agony rippled through the crowd like a shockwave, everyone reeling from the half-telepathic wail as it reverberated inside their heads as well as their ears. Half-stunned, Tyger fell to the ground, both hands cupped over her ears. Above her, Marr tore the dirk from his eye. Green mist seemed to boil out of him.
So that's what a bog wraith's blood looks like, Shalar mused.
122112211111111111.title: Foggy Blood

1221122111111111111.content:
"you will pay for that, gargoyle. your death will be long, slow, and miserable!" Marr floated down until his ghostly form was almost touching the ground. His remaining eye glared at Tyger's huddled figure. "and you will never face ryan in the arena. you will die at my hands long before that day."
Tyger's eyes flashed, and in an instant, she shot up from the ground, her other dirk poised like a scorpion's tail, aimed at Marr.
"That was the wrong thing to say, bitch," she hissed, and drove her dirk straight into Marr's face.
A ripple of pure agony shook Marr as he collapsed to the ground.
1221122111111111111.title: Wrong answer, bitch

12211221111111111111.content:
Tyger was knocked down by the shockwave of pain Marr gave off, and many in the crowd screamed as the weaker minds were battered by the telepathic blast.
The gargoyle slowly pulled herself back to her feet, finding Marr slumped on the ground, a sickly yellow-green color. Both his eyes were faded, rust-colored spots, and Tyger was sure he was temporarily blind. That is, at least temporarily... She pulled her dirks from the ground and staggered towards the Arena doors.

"And now, it's my turn." Shalar sighed and excused himself from the combatants' terrace, making his way to the staging area in the stones below. I've got to learn magic. My blades may be immune to spells, but I'm not. Beating Elise was far too difficult... He blinked, splashing the stone walls with gold light, before he stepped out into the afternoon sunlight.
At the far end of the Arena's bowl stood Sarah Nicolshki. I can't help but wonder...as Ryan's friend, is she a target for Tyger as well...?
"Good afternoon, Sarah," he said, bowing. Sarah just chuckled. "Knock it off, Shalar. How am I supposed to fight you if you're being nice, hm?"
"That's the general idea. I don't want to fight you, or Ryan, or even Johnathan. I'm just here for David's death."
"Sad purpose, Shalar. You know he had nothing to do with Harac, and for the longest time didn't even know Harac was his brother."
Shalar's eyes narrowed. "You're lying, you have to be. I've seen that man, twenty paces in front of me, as he killed my brother Reivus. You can't tell me he had nothing to do with Harac- those were his troops David was commanding!"
Sarah shook her head, ignoring the Arena master as he dropped the flag. Shalar stood likewise, ignoring the signal to start the fight. "Shalar, they were brothers. Of course they would look alike. The man you saw was most likely Harac himself. Your need for vengeance is long past."
12211221111111111111.title: Revelation

choices: A meeting with the Arena master
122112211111111111111.content:
A chant was starting in the stands, several hundred people shouting at Shalar and Sarah both to fight. The pair ignored them all.
"My long hunt, my fights here...all for nothing..?" Shalar muttered, half to himself, half to Sarah. "But to give up now will not bring closure. And now I know, killing David will not either. How am I supposed to end this, then?"
Sarah put her arm on Shalar's shoulder, careful not to cut herself on the hooked blade there. "I can't tell you that. Only you will be able to answer that. And you shall, when the time comes." She shook her head. "I cede this fight to you. Winning most of my other fights will still allow me a place to challenge Calarith, when the time comes." She knelt, touching her knee to the dusty ground, then turned and walked from the Arena. For a moment, Shalar just stood there, contemplating what Sarah had said. Then he too, left the Arena. Neither noticed the rising tide of jeers that followed them from the battleground.
122112211111111111111.title: Redirected Hunt

choices: "Send Raven to kill him. If he survives, he is worthy of David's challen
"Send David. Give the crowd something to remember."
1221122111111111111111.content:
"What the hell is wrong with you, Shalar? Those people expect a fight, pay for a fight!"
Shalar was deep in one end of the staging area, getting thoroughly chewed out by the Arena master. And yet, I don't feel bad about it at all...
"I will fight my enemies, I will fight those I am pitted against because they become my enemies, but I will not fight my friends. Sarah is a friend, and I will not raise a single blade to her until she gives me due cause to do so."
The Arena master reddened with fury. How dare he lecture me?!? I control the Arena- the bouts, the time, the very combatants!
"Having a temper tantrum won't help. I will not fight anyone if they refuse to give me a reason to." Without waiting to be dismissed, Shalar turned and walked calmly from the staging area to the barracks. He found Tyger lying still on the top bunk, half her head swathed in bandages. Laconically, she turned the uncovered eye towards him.
"Psyonic shock. Marr practically exploded telepathically when I downed him." Carefully, she rubbed a palm at her bandaged temple, wincing as she did.
Shalar simply nodded. "Half the spectators were unable to walk without support, and roughly ten were seen vomiting outside the Arena's entrance. One of those landed it on an orderly's boot."
Tyger laughed painfully. "How bad did our beloved Arena master chew you out?"
"Not bad, all things considered. But I know he's cooking up something. He won't let this slide, especially not the way he's been manipulating the fights lately. For all I know, he might pit me against David for a grudge match, or he might simply decide to go with a big finish and have Calarith kill me."
Tyger's eyes widened. "You think he would do that? Send Calarith on you?" Shalar simply nodded again.
"I believe he'd do anything if the need called for it. After all, he allowed Ryan to be sold to this battle, with full knowledge of his predicament, and drafted Ressek into the fights simply because he was helping Siph off the field."
"If you had to fight Calarith, do you think you could beat him?"
Shalar laughed, an ugly, almost panic stricken laugh. "He would tear me apart in moments. I may be fast, but I don't think I'm ready to beat the Arena's champion. Hell, I'd be lucky to live through Raven right now."

Night had fallen on the Arena, and the last bout was coming to an end. Calarith stood regally on his terrace, joined by the Arena master. The man had made his way up here, to this highest point of his Arena to gain counsel from Calarith.
"He is an obstinate one, no doubt. But I refuse to believe it is necessary for me to kill him. He will make a fine challenger when he is properly weathered." Calarith's voice was low but cultured, giving him an air of superiority that he exploited at any encounter. Of course, humans are so easily cowed by appearances. My size alone would do well...but why resort to such barbaric measures as physical intimidation? Politics have such a finesse to them. Calarith turned, fixing his eyes on the man who provided this battlefield he presided over. "Ultimately, it is your decision. How severe is too far?"
"But that's the problem- I don't know whether to reward him and the crowd with a glorious battle, like his long-time hate, David, or to send someone deadly and finish him!" The Arena master held his head in his hands, his shoulder-length hair clinging to his sweaty cheeks. He looked up at the great dragon. "I'm at a loss, Calarith. For perhaps the first time in my life, I don't know what to do."
Such a fool of a human. It's amazing they survive as they do, but I suppose he is a poor example. It's humans like Ryan and Elise that make up the backbone of their survival. Whether they acknowledge it or not... Calarith closed his eyes in thought, then fixed them on the Arena master again.
1221122111111111111111.title: Decisions, decisions...

choices: Shalar leaps and meets the charge
12211221111111111111111.content:
"Send Raven to kill Shalar. If he lives, he may fight David." Calarith turned away and was about to leap off the terrace when he paused. His large finned head swiveled back and fixed its eyes on the Arena master once more. "This is the last time I will do your thinking for you, human." Then he threw himself skyward, off into the forests outside the Arena to hunt dinner.

The next day dawned bright and cloudless, but as Shalar made his way into the staging area, he could feel a storm gathering. A summer squall, the kind that sneaks in from the horizon and drenches everything with rain and lightning before passing through and leaving a humid fog everywhere. He shook his head, clearing it, and stepped into the Arena. A thin gray line of storm clouds hunkered on the horizon, preparing to pounce. It gave the Arena the feel of a true battlefield, one where armies of warring kingdoms clashed, hundreds of men fighting and dying, hacked to pieces, or doing the hacking. The storm gathers...
Opposite him, there was nothing but the stone doors. They slowly rumbled open, and Shalar saw iron gates behind it. That could only mean one thing. There's only one fighter here nasty enough to need channel gates. Raven! Shalar glanced up at the Arena master, holding the red cloth above the Arena. He actually smiled at Shalar when he noticed the creature's gaze fall on him. The price of insolence is meant to be death...but when did Raven become the assasin? It didn't matter. The Arena's keeper dropped his cloth, and with a ghastly screech, the gates were drawn open, leaving the sleek black dragonet tearing into the field of battle. The minute he saw Shalar, his eyes narrowed, and he threw himself into the air, preparing to dive at Shalar like a hawk.
12211221111111111111111.title: The Storm Gathers

122112211111111111111111.content:
Shalar watched as the dragon leapt into the air, spreading its wings to gain a bit more altitude before diving at him. I can't let him run the fight. He'll hunt me down and kill me if I go evasive... With grim determination and a sinking fear in his stomach, Shalar crouched low on his long legs and threw himself at Raven's diving figure.
Raven's eyes widened in surprise as Shalar sprang up at him, hooked blades at the ready. He squeezed off one startled, angry chirp before Shalar's elbow blade landed flat across his throat, gagging him.
Choking and coughing, the dragonet fell hard to earth. In comparison, Shalar landed lightly on his long toe-blades and whipped his tail out, puncturing Raven's left wing, then tearing a huge rent in it as he ripped the hooked blade free. Raven gasped and squealed in pain, but was on his feet an instant later. His eyes tracked every movement Shalar made, trying to gauge when the bladed creature would be most vulnerable.

"I don't like this. Shalar is doing far too well against that little dragon." The Arena master shook his head. "The pounding he took from Ressek early on must've dulled him. Look how cautious he is in his attacks now."
"Caution is a trait well learned by a dragon, or even dragonet," Calarith hissed. "All creatures should be possessed of some measure of it. Those who are not are too easily defeated." The great dragon nodded at Raven's circling. "Such as the leap he made at Shalar in the beginning. Brash and bloodthirsty, and it has cost him dearly already."

Raven hissed and snapped at Shalar, trying to force a move other than his solid "double-guard" position, crossing both his upper and lower forearms in a double X that would easily thwart any hasty moves. Blood. I must have his blood! I cannot even smell it yet- I have not blooded him! I must! Raven feinted a charge to Shalar's left flank, then as Shalar moved to block him, his tail lashed out to hit Shalar in the legs, unbalancing him. Oh shit! No! I can't fall! Not this close to him!
122112211111111111111111.title: Lessons learned

1221122111111111111111111.content:
For a moment, Shalar struggled to keep himself upright. But as he saw Raven swing in line with him, ready for another attack, he gave himself up to gravity.
With a vicious, chirping squeal, Raven launched himself at Shalar. But as Shalar fell, he brought his tail up between his legs, catching the hook in Raven's scaled stomach and flinging him well over Shalar's head. The dragonet landed in a puff of dust, whirling on Shalar the minute his feet hit the ground.
Now I've made him mad. Just wonderful... Pivoting on his newly regained legs, Shalar back-handed the dragonet, who was just now charging him again. The blow snapped Raven's head to the side, throwing the dragonet off balance and tumbling to the side. Once again, the little dragon tumbled through the dirt, chirping furiously.
Grounding him is one thing, but how do I beat him?
1221122111111111111111111.title: Dusted

choices: Like Tyger before him, Raven gets up
12211221111111111111111111.content:
Raven picked himself up once again, nearly knocking Shalar back with the hatred boiling from his eyes. He trilled a long, chirping hiss and began circling the bladed creature who was knocking him around.
Shalar was waiting for him to make his move, but when it came, he still wasn't prepared. In an instant, Raven went from careful stalking to a sudden lunge, directly at Shalar's throat. The two of them fell backwards, Shalar desperately trying to hold Raven off his jugular. The dragonet's claws raked his arms and sides furiously, scrabbling madly in his attempt to drive his sharp teeth into Shalar's throat. Then the dragonet made his mistake. His wings fluttered open, trying to gain purchase in the air that would give him the extra push needed to reach Shalar's throat. That gave Shalar all the opportunity he needed, kicking out with his powerful legs to drive Raven skyward. His wings caught the air enough to drag him backwards, away from Shalar. As he fell back, the bladed creature's claws shot out, grabbing the dragonet by his own throat and ribcage, digging in slightly with their sharp hooks. With one fluid motion, Shalar turned, flinging Raven at the portion of wall closest to them. As with Tyger in his first fight, Raven struck the wall hard. He collapsed to the ground, chest barely moving, his breathing shallow.
And yet, if he gets up, he's still a dangerous enemy.
12211221111111111111111111.title: History Repeats Itself

122112211111111111111111111.content:
But Raven didn't move, his draconic form sprawled against the stones like a discarded cloak. After a minute, Shalar turned and walked slowly to the doors, where a reluctant nod from the Arena master told the guards to let him pass. Once again, he was welcomed into the cool stones of the staging area, and out of the morning sun.

"Raven continues to live, and I am left without an inkling as to what challenger I'll face next. Damn this whole place!" Shalar banged his fist on the table in frustration, causing his plate to jump. "And even facing David won't solve my problems. Seeing how empty Elise is after Raven, and then to find out David wasn't the one I seek anyway...My whole existence has been turned upside down!"
Tyger laid a hand on his arm, stilling another blow to the mess table. "If it wasn't David who killed Reivus, then who? Perhaps Johnathan?"
"No, I've seen John. He looks nothing like the man who lead that attack on the mercenaries." Shalar slumped against the table's edge, drained of all energy and purpose. "I'm nothing more than a zombie, Tyger. The 'fighting' dead as it were."
"And yet you defeated Raven, against your own confidence that you could. Focus on your fights, Shalar, not your revenge."
"Dammit, Tyger, that is my fight! How can I continue with no purpose?" Without waiting for an answer, he stood and left the mess hall.
As he walked down the cool hallways towards his barracks room, an idea began forming. But for it to work, he had to be fighting Ryan next. Only Ryan would join me in this- his purpose is as great. And if the man I seek is who I think he is, he will help me every step of the way...
122112211111111111111111111.title: Turning Point

1221122111111111111111111111.content:
It was just after noon when Shalar again stepped into the Arena. The crowds were somewhat subdued from the heat, but that mattered little to him. David Talis stood at the far end of the grounds, his hands clasped behind his back, head bowed. Meditating, or just riding out the heat?

The Arena master saw that Shalar had entered the Arena and his eyes narrowed. Never the less, he strode to the edge of his terrace, announced the start of the fight, and dropped the red cloth yet again.
Calmly, David walked towards Shalar, who studied him thoroughly in turn. "You're not the one who commanded the attack on my brother's mercenary company, are you, David?"
"I have no idea what you're talking about. I know nothing of a mercenary company."
"Damn. As I suspected, then."
"You wish to kill me, to exact some sort of revenge, don't you? I only wish I knew what for, but I assure you I'll make it very difficult."
Shalar bowed his head, the long blade on it nearly slicing David's forehead. "No, you're not the one I'm after. You're nothing like him. A cruel, rude man with sandy blonde hair and cold gray eyes."
1221122111111111111111111111.title: It was never David...

12211221111111111111111111111.content:
"That sounds like his son...my nephew Kane." David shuddered, thinking how he would feel if his own son were the target of Shalar's aggression. "I won't give him over to you. He may be evil, he may be a bastard, and he may be the one who killed your brother and sold Ryan into slavery, but he is family and you'll have to slice your way through me to reach him." Having said his piece, David straightened, his eyes glowing yellow with the lycanthropic power he possessed.
"You're a fool then, David. Such a man deserves death, and Death deserves him. If you wish to stand in my way, Aumer himself won't save you." Shalar's eyes flashed in return, though for him it was just blinking.
The Arena master's cloth hit the ground and immediately, the gathering storm broke. Torrents of rain rushed over the Arena's grounds, drenching everything. Above it, lightnight flashed, illuminating everything in a ghostly blue twilight even though it was midday. Heedless of the weather, David and Shalar went at it.
The lycanthrope dodged backwards, Shalar's claws raking the air where his stomach once was. As he rolled, he began to change, and when he stopped his evasion, a large gray wolf stood, poised on its four legs and growling fiercely.
"David, you throw your life away for nothing. I can see now- it was never you I wanted dead..." Shalar's voice trailed off in a whisper, knowing deep in his heart that David would either walk away from this the victor- or not at all...
12211221111111111111111111111.title: Mortal Decision

choices: Shalar tries to talk sense to David
122112211111111111111111111111.content:
David ignored the whisper, although his sensitive wolf ears could easily hear it. He sank low for a moment, and launched himself at Shalar. Knowing the creature would block his throat instinctively, David tried to flank Shalar, nipping at his ankles, trying to get a bite in.
But he forgot about Shalar's tail.
The heavy brass-colored blade knocked David well back with a piercing yelp. A long gash was opened up along his ribs as the hooked tip tore his side.
122112211111111111111111111111.title: Forgotten Tail

1221122111111111111111111111111.content:
David picked himself up from the ground, gave a cursory lick to his side, and charged Shalar again. Trying to do as little harm to the werewolf as possible, Shalar moved to block another attack, but wasn't expecting David's next move.
With a nimble leap, the wolf shot up over Shalar and landed just behind the bladed creature. Again, the tail came into play, but this time David was able to dodge it, and leapt on Shalar from behind, bringing him down. But even that was not enough.
Shalar rolled as he hit the ground, lashing out with a long, powerful kick. David was sent sprawling as the thick limb crashed into his already injured side, the long toe-claws raking his wounded ribs further.
Slowly, Shalar stood.
"David, this won't get us anywhere. Why can't you see that? Kane is no more family to you than a simulacrum." But David, though he could hear the whispered pleas, simply struggled to stand once more, intent on his futile goal.
1221122111111111111111111111111.title: Futility

choices: Shalar plans his escape from the Arena
12211221111111111111111111111111.content:
Realizing that his wolf form could do little against Shalar, David melted back into human. Blood still leaked from his side, but the cut had sealed itself somewhat- a side effect of changing forms. "Shalar, you are correct. The family aspect matters little. But do not live your life around vengeance- eventually, it will break you. Ryan is a shell of who he once was. It would be a shame for you to follow his path." Painfully, David waved to the terrace where the Arena master stood. The man grimaced, but threw down a sword, which landed point down in the dirt, several feet away. Shalar motioned to him to pick it up, and he did so, wincing as he knelt to pull it from the ground.
"Ryan has led a hard life, David. I merely wish to let Reivus rest easy in his grave."
"It is of no consequence, Shalar. You live for vengeance, and it will destroy you. You live for the death of my nephew, and so I must destroy you, or die trying."
Shalar glared at David, his eyes flashing a brilliant gold, but he said nothing. He knew there would be no arguing with David. Wordlessly, they went at each other again.
Steel clashed on blade as they circled the floor of the Arena. Each thrust, each slash, each blow David tried or blocked hurt him a great deal, Shalar could see that. He winced as the hits resonated through his body, sending lances of pain through his injured side.
Shalar crossed his arms just in time, blocking a mighty overhand chop that would have cleaved his bladed skull. Growling between the locked blades, he said to David, "It's over, Talis. It was over before you entered this Arena."
David grunted with exertion, trying to force the blade down, to push back Shalar. "If you never knew it was Kane," David gasped, "would my death have brought you closure?"
"Perhaps. But I think somewhere I would've known I had failed." Shalar pushed back with all his might, flinging David and his heavy sword back several steps. They both paused for a breather.
Shalar glanced at David's hunched form, struggling to draw in the needed, fighting his wounds. "Deep down, I would've known it wasn't you after all."
Time slowed for everyone as Shalar walked slowly to where David hunched. He drew back one arm and landed a backhanded blow that snapped David's head around. Wordlessly, Talis crumpled to the ground as though a puppet with its strings cut. Thin red lines traced over his cheek, where the hooks had bit into him despite Shalar's use of the rounded outer edge of his blades.
"I declare this fight finished, David. I refuse to kill someone so bent on saving me from myself."
12211221111111111111111111111111.title: Broken Vengeance

122112211111111111111111111111111.content:
David groaned and tried to sit up. "As long as you still hunt Kane, Shalar, I have failed in that," he rasped. Then he was silenced as the Arena's healer-mages tended his wounds.
Silently, Shalar turned and left the unconcious werewolf. A voice in the back of his mind echoed David's last words. As long as you still hunt Kane, Shalar, I have failed in that. 'I have failed...' Damn it all, he's right! Shalar brushed past the two guards at the battlefield's exit without a second thought, headed straight for his barracks. Behind him, the storm broke over the dusty ground, soaking the dirt and washing the blood from it.

"Tyger, he's right. Damn it all, I had to stop and think about it! He's right!"
Shalar banged a clawed arm in frustration against the stone walls of the barracks room. "My quest for vengeance will lead no where except through a path of hellish suffering and disappointment. Elise, Ryan, you, all follow the same path." He sighed. "Somehow, I hoped mine would be different, but I see now that it isn't."
Tyger merely stared at him, reclining on the top bunk.
"And what would you do if that weren't the case? There's no other reason you're here."
Shalar paused in his agitated pacing, glanced up at her. Why else AM I here...? I came to find and kill David. Then my mission was against Kane. Kane is not here...Neither should I be. Gold light flashed the walls as he blinked. "There's no other reason I'm here...There's no other reason why I'm here!" He repeated Tyger's words to himself, growing more confident in their meaning with each passing moment.
"Shalar, have you finally flipped?"
"Tyger, that's it! I don't belong here, I never did! This whole thing was a fool's quest!" Shalar grew excited as he began pulling supplies into a pack. Bandages, herbs, plenty of room for food...Damn, I know what I'm doing. I know why. But I don't know how. How do I get out of here? They won't just let me leave. "I'm leaving. I will seek Kane out, kill him, and even if my road to vengeance is hell, I will have that vengeance. And when I fall, and fall I will, it will be me alone who goes down. And that won't be until after Kane does."
With a new sense of purpose and a determination to match, Shalar strode out of the room, heading for the mess hall. Surprise, that's what I'll need. Brush past the guards at the exit, knock them down, and run like hell! Aumer help me, this won't be easy...
122112211111111111111111111111111.title: 'I have failed'

1221122111111111111111111111111111.content:
"Shalar, why are you packing food into that haversack? The mess is open long enough- you don't need stores in your room."
Shalar grumbled something noncommittal to the cook and continued stocking himself up. I'd like to take more, but that chef is going to get suspicious. Better go now.
"Thanks anyway. I'll be fine," Shalar assured him, and left as quickly as possible.

His white skin made it difficult to hide and be inconspicous, but somehow Shalar managed to get within the last turn of the main gate. A thin stream of spectators flowed both in and out, some coming for the fights, some leaving them. I'll have to act fast- knock one guard asides, maybe two. I'm glad security is lax at this end of the Arena.
Shalar pulled himself from the wall, and was ready to charge the unsuspecting guards when a gloved hand tapped him on one of his armored shoulders.
"Going somewhere, Shalar?"
1221122111111111111111111111111111.title: Discovered?

12211221111111111111111111111111111.content:
Shalar wheeled, but found himself facing only Ryan. "I followed you- I want to get out of here as much as you do, Shalar, but Calarith is too close. He wants to fight you, and badly. He will certainly chase you down if you try to escape, even if you make it past those idiots there."
"That's why you followed me? To warn me about the dragon?"
"Not completely. The time to escape isn't right, Shalar. Don't make that your only goal." Ryan stared hard at the bladed creature. "Surviving will be more difficult."
"Surviving? What do you mean?"
"Your next fight is right after Ressek's and Sarah's...and if I'm not mistaken, they're fighting now. Krath will be waiting for you."
Shalar blinked, flashing the walls with gold phosphorenes. "Krath? They would waste their time with that brute?"
"Yes. They hope that he will be strong enough to kill you. That Arena master wants you dead, Shalar. Desperately." Ryan's head swiveled, facing back down the passage, away from the exit. They could both hear the crowd cheering something. "It has ended. Your fight with Krath awaits."
Turning, Ryan left him there, debating whether to escape or to face Krath and earn his freedom. I have time to spare, unlike Ryan. If he can afford to wait, I can also. But Kane gets farther away with each day... Mentally, Shalar chided himself. Honestly, he didn't have a clue where Kane was, although he was sure that Harac's son was returning to finish off Ryan's family.
12211221111111111111111111111111111.title: Draconic Warning

122112211111111111111111111111111111.content:
It will take me time to find Kane anyway- that is time best spent preparing. Krath awaits...

Shalar did not pause as he passed through the staging area, though for once he armed himself. He entered the Arena and strode right to its center with a confidence of purpose that frightened himself. In his left claws, he carried a long spear, which rose a good foot or more above his own 7'6" height. Krath has survived too long already. If the Arena master thinks to make this encounter my death, he is sorely mistaken. I am not some simple brute to be put down with greater strength. Out of one eye, he saw the Arena master returning to his terrace. The red cloth was held ready as he introduced the competitors. Shalar swore the man winked at him as he spoke Krath's name. That tears it. I refuse to follow their rules any more.
122112211111111111111111111111111111.title: Rising Blood

1221122111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Krath almost laughed at the disgusted expression on Shalar's face as he glanced at the Arena master. Suddenly, he was afraid. Shalar was walking towards him again, even though the fight had not begun. Krath stared plaintively at the Arena master, who promptly gave up his introductions and dropped the cloth. But it was too late.

Shalar grinned at Krath as his left arm shot out, burying the spear deep inside Krath's midsection. Krath roared and doubled over in pain, but his anguished cry was cut short as Shalar's right claws shot out, their hooked ends snapping shut around his throat. Krath gurgled in horror, his simple mind racing as it sank in dispair.
"I would say this is for some purpose," Shalar hissed, digging his claws in, "but I'm just proving a point." With that, he jerked his claws back, ripping Krath's throat out. Black blood spurted high into the air as Krath fell forward, twitching spasmodically. His eyes were open to an eternity they could not see, his mouth to a scream he could never voice.
And his throat, to a purpose he could never understand, Shalar finished, and left the Arena.

"You dropped the cloth. The battle was started before Shalar thrust that spear. There is nothing you can do against him, Arena master," Calarith growled. "You will have to let him face me, however much you personally hate him."
1221122111111111111111111111111111111.title: To Prove A Point

12211221111111111111111111111111111111.content:
"So, instead of fighting Krath fairly, you ran him through with a spear the
instant the flag dropped, and then tore his throat out?" Tyger gazed at Shalar
over the edge of her bunk with bored half-interest. "I'm starting to admire
you."
"The last words he ever heard were me telling him he could not understand the
reason he died that way." Shalar glanced up at her. "That's no way to die, not
even knowing why you lose your life."
"But you've made your point- I saw Calarith and the Arena master arguing, and I
know who will win that battle. Calarith relishes the challenge, while the
master wants you dead. I suspect they'll get it both ways- dead at the claws of
the dragon." Tyger pulled herself back onto the bunk and stared at the ceiling,
her words echoing Shalar's own cascading thoughts. "But I can't help
wondering...what will the Arena master try next?"
"Marr would've been my guess, but he's still far to weak to fight, thanks to
your victory. I doubt we'll see him in the Arena again this tournament. No, most
likely I will face Johnathan Talis. The shapeshifter can change into whatever
form he sees most fit, including a small dragon."
"Raven already failed- you think-"
"Bigger than Raven, Tyger. The size of a horse. Those are still small dragons,
comparatively, but much more powerful than a dragonet like Raven."

"Calarith, if you want to fight him so badly, then call him out now. Challenge
him early, if you wish. Otherwise, let me run my Arena according to the
rules I have laid out."
"Those rules have turned on you already, Arena warden." Calarith refused to call
anyone save a greater dragon his 'master.' "Shalar played them against you, and
it has cost Krath his life."
"And it may well cost Johnathan his life as well, as it nearly did his father's.
The bladed one fights the shapeshifter, and he does so tonight."
12211221111111111111111111111111111111.title: Specultions and Schemes

122112211111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Torchlight ringed the Arena, bathing the dusty bowl in a flickering halo of
light. The Arena master was growing frustrated. That damn Shalar takes on
anything I throw at him, and spits it right back in my face! If I were able, I
would kill him myself- but what chance do I have against that? Humans
weren't made for such things.
Scowling in frustration, he stepped to the terrace. Below, Shalar and Johnathan
faced each other. Noticing him, Shalar turned. The expression on his face sent
chills down the Arena master's spine. He means to kill me, I know it. Some
how, he wishes me dead.

"Talis, look at our Arena master. Does he remind you of someone?" Shalar glared
hard at the man on the terrace. "There's something vaguely familiar about
him."
"Keep your attention on me, Shalar, or you will regret it. You spared my father,
and I shall spare you, but do not expect more than that. Your vendetta nearly
cost him his life, and I have gone too long without my father to see him die in
this awful place."
"Spare me your attitude, Talis. My vengeance is not with David. He nearly threw
his own life away to save me from myself. If anything, I owe him a debt of
gratitude for it."
"Thanking him will not erase the fact that you nearly killed him, Shalar!"
Johnathan was growing angry, and Shalar didn't know what to do about it.
Fortunately, it was then that the Arena master released the red cloth he held.
It took on a shade of deep rust as it dropped into the shadows near the walls,
disappearing into the darkness.
"Then give him my best regards in the infirmary," Shalar said evenly, and
pivoted on his right leg, bringing his tail to bear in a round-house blow that
knocked John to the ground. A thin line of blood welled up on his cheek- Shalar
had not been entirely successful in keeping his tail-blade's hook from the
blow.
The time for talk had ended. Now Talis was out for blood- Shalar's honey-colored
blood.
122112211111111111111111111111111111111.title: Rising Tempers

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Johnathan picked himself up, brushing away the dirt. Wordlessly, his form
wavered, growing larger and more muscular. His skin darkened molding itself into
a hard black shell. Spikes stretched out from multiple spots on his arms, legs,
and back.
A demon...he managed to acquire the spirit of a demon. He is more skilled
than I thought. Warily, Shalar took a step back.
Moments later, Talis was no more. A huge black demon, larger than Krath and
covered in hard black armor, stood in his place.
Shalar's eyes immediately began seeking a weakness, a flaw in Johnathan's new
form, but he could not find any. How did you ever manage to acquire this
form, Talis? Shalar wondered in awe.
The demon returned Shalar's blow with fervor, knocking him backwards, nearly to
the wall. His bronze claws shone dully in the shadowy light.
Damn! Strong magery would have trouble with this beast. How do I beat
it?
The answer came as an echo in Shalar's mind, ever so faintly standing out among
his words, "strong magery...magic..." repeating itself in his mind.
But I am not skilled in magic! I have no innate talents! Shalar argued
with himself. How can I use magic when I have none? Talis started towards
him, eyes nothing more than glowing red dots among a mountain of hard insect
armor and thorny spikes.
"Magic...strong magery," Shalar's mind repeated. As he stood, rising to
face Talis again, his claws brushed the stone wall of the Arena. Something
twitched in his mind again, a new answer inserting itself within the reply of
magery. "Demons from the ground must be swallowed by the ground...use magic,
Shalar."
I'm going crazy. I'm asking myself things, and getting answers. But I have to
try, don't I?
Talis took another heavy step forward, shaking the ground beneath Shalar's
clawed feet.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Demon of Talis

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Shalar didn't know what to do. Voices were telling him to use magic, and in such
a desperate situation, he was inclined to listen. But I don't know how to use
magic! I don't have any! Still, I have to try. It's likely my only hope of
survival.
He focused on air, his vision becoming blurred. Reaching as deep within himself
as possible, Shalar searched around, trying to push aside or unlock
something.
Talis came another step closer.
Shalar felt himself hit rock bottom- there was no deeper level he could find.
But if such power is so well buried, then would it not be entombed?
Mentally, Shalar swatted himself. He didn't know what that meant, but the echoes
of the magic calling him could be felt beyond whatever barrier he had found.
Pulling with all his might, he felt something give. Slowly, the barrier fell.
The demonic Johnathan raised one arm, reaching out for Shalar as he stood in
silence. To most, it would appear that he was frozen in fear.

Calarith knew differently.
Shalar has magical ability? Why has he not used it be- but of course, he
would not have known. Only now does he start to unlock his powers. Properly
trained, he may have been a great mage, but even this late in life he could
still be dangerous. Below, it was quickly becoming apparent that Shalar's
stupor was not what it appeared.

Gold light welled up beneath Shalar, flickering in static bolts up his blades.
Flaming and sparking, the released magic dripped from his claws. As if in a
trance, he raised his arms.
Johnathan paused- this was not the same creature he had faced moments earlier.
Like himself, a change had occurred. When did Shalar gain magical abilities?
He is not trained in any form of magery...is he? The crackling energy
pulsing through Shalar's bronze blades gave lie to any further doubts that he
was possessed of magical talent. And a lot of it...
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Power Within

choices: Shalar wakes in his barracks room
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Johnathan backed away slowly, not fully realizing what he was doing. Even the
demon's soul in this form was afraid, cowering before the surge of raw power
before him. The earth itself seemed to rise up through Shalar, giving him
energies he had never before witnessed. Before he knew it, his back was against
the far wall, and still Shalar seemed right before him. And indeed, something
was coming closer, though not Shalar.
Ripples of gold light flowed from underneath Shalar, stretching out in a narrow
band that traced its way along the ground to where Johnathan stood, in demon
form. A short distance from reaching him, the ground under the magic cracked. A
heartbeat later, hundreds of tendrils of magic snaked out from the ground,
wrapping around Johnathan's arms, legs, neck, and waist. Far beyond the crack,
