Johnathan could just make out Shalar's glowing form on the far side of the
battleground.

Shalar saw dimly that his magic was tangling itself around Johnathan. "Now
pull. Pull!" the voices echoed. They had been right thus far, and Shalar saw
no reason to ignore them now. Not knowing why or how, he pulled the tendrils
back, as hard as he could.

Johnathan screamed in pain as his demon form was litterally torn from him. A
shadowy image that might have been the demon's acquired soul hovered in the air
before him, though his vision was blurred with tears as he shut his eyes hard to
the pain. He lay on the dusty ground in human form, rich purple blood soaking
him and the dirt around him. Bellowing in rage and terror, the demon's soul was
pulled under the ground, and the crack sealed itself with a bright golden
flash.

Shalar felt the rumble as the ground sealed itself. Suddenly, the magic he had
unleashed was gone, and the "stone door" he had opened sealed itself within
again, the voices retreating beyond it and out of reach. Completely drained,
Shalar sank to his knees. Above him, he could just make out through his clearing
eyesight the Arena master, red with rage, declaring him the winner. Golden
phosphorenes shone for an instant as Shalar blinked. I won...Arena master,
you podgy bastard, I won. With those final thoughts, Shalar collapsed into
blackness.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Golden Tendrils

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
When he next awoke, Shalar found himself on a flat, hard bed. Morning sunlight
streamed weakly through high, narrow windows overhead Oof! Feels like a straw
pallet on a stone. Sitting up further, he realized that was just the case.
What kind of place is this..? A white-clad Arena orderly gave him his
answer.
"Shalar, good, you're awake. We were beginning to wonder," she said, and put
down a sheet of parchment. "Do you know what happened?"
"I defeated Johnathan. Then I blacked out," Shalar said blandly.
"You are what is known as a 'wild talent,' someone with innate but nearly
uncontrolable natural powers. Yours come from an earth element, apparently," she
said with mild interest, looking over the parchment records. "And you've
completely drained yourself, or so we think."
"So you think?" Shalar repeated.
"Apparently, whatever magical reserves you have are locked very deep within.
Because of that, sensing the levels of such magic is very difficult, often
misleading, and that is why it has taken until now for you to use them- a 'wild
talent' must be pressed hard to reveal their abilities." She offered him a
sympathetic glance. "An unbeatable demon would qualify."
"If he was unbeatable, then why did I win?" Shalar asked cautiously. This ordery
did not look like someone who would tolerate an offense.
"You didn't defeat the demon, Shalar. You returned him. Johnathan's
shape-shifting abilities come from acquiring a copy of the creature's soul. By
using these copies, he can become virtually anything he wants to. But inside is
still his form. Your magic tore the demon's form from him, and returned it to
its own realm. Johnathan was almost killed," she added sadly.
Shalar blinked. Surely she doesn't have interest in him? he thought, but
left the thought unspoken.
"In any event, you are fit to return to competition. But be warned- try to
release much more of that magic and you'll find yourself in much worse shape
than simple exhaustion."
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Wild Talent?

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Shalar made his way slowly down to the mess hall. Despite the orderly's report,
he did not believe he was ready yet to return to battle. It's been too long
since I've eaten. I need strength. And food. I wonder if my pack is still
filled? It should be in the barracks then...yes, less of a trip. Choosing a
different corridor, Shalar made his way back to his barracks room. Tyger was
waiting for him- and so was someone else.
What is Ressek doing here? Shalar wondered, and asked Tyger aloud.
"I came to ask you about Siph, Shalar," Ressek replied, turning from the window
to face his next competitor. "Don't kill him. Whatever you do, don't kill
him."
"Ressek, I make every effort to let my competition live, except in rare
cases-"
"Krath."
"Krath was a fool, and reveled in destruction. That does not justify his death
any more than the true reason I killed him, but I will not repeat such an act
again." Shalar pulled his pack from under his bunk, rummaging for something
edible. No one spoke for a moment.
It was Tyger who at last broke the silence. "Why ask this, Ressek?"
"Because, Siph has his own magical abilities. I recognize Shalar for what he is-
a wild talent who will unleash some of the most powerful magic I've ever seen if
hard pressed. I do not wish to see Siph meet the same end as the demon before
him." Ressek clasped his long-fingered hands on Shalar's shoulder-blades. "And
believe me, you will be hard pressed. Siph wishes to win for glory, and
that sort of ambition is more than enough to drive him on." Ressek shook his
head sadly and released Shalar's shoulders. "He has something to prove, and is
very desperate to do so."
"Desperate people make too many mistakes, Ressek. Tell him that. If he needs an
example, he can look to the lowest terrace of the Arena in his next fight."
"The Arena master...?"
"He is very desperate to see me dead. His tournament-long conspiracy is
being unraveled simply because I fight in my own style, and he has taken drastic
lengths to see me dead in the Arena."
"And of course, he wouldn't have you die any other way." Ressek turned back to
the window. "He is a fool indeed."
"Not to interrupt this wonderful talk, but I have a fight with Elise to win,"
Tyger said, and pulled both her dirks from the wall as she made her exit. Shalar
watched her go, wondering how much she had changed from the hate-filled creature
she had been in the beginning.
"And what of you, Ressek?" Shalar asked, when she had gone.
"I do not care, Shalar. It was not my choice to be in this Arena, and I will be
happy if all I do is survive it." Ressek shuddered. "My last fight will be with
Elise. I pray that it is not my last fight."
Silently, he too made his exit, leaving Shalar alone in the barracks room.
As the end winds down, so do our spirits. We are all tired of fighting, and
Ressek most of all. Krath, Raven, Marr, they are the lucky ones. Their fight is
over.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Barracks Conspiracy

choices: "Fight it, Ressek. Do not give up hope now."
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
The morning sun was high in the sky when Shalar entered the Arena. This is
it- the last day of the tournament. The last day I shall have to face my friends
over the field of battle.
Shalar's good mood was marred when he saw Ressek's expression. The poor reptile
had an expression so vacant it could have swallowed a desert. The emptiness and
apathy in his eyes was startling. I didn't realize these fights had been so
hard on him...I must be careful not to hurt him too badly.
Even the Arena master seemed apathetic as he dropped the flag. All his attempts
to kill Shalar had failed, and the best he could hope for was that Shalar would
win his other fights and die in Calarith's claws, a bloody sacrifice to the
Champion of the Arena.
"And so it begins again, Ressek," Shalar said, walking towards the martial
artist.
"Indeed. End it quickly, Shalar. I am tired of life."
Shalar's mind reeled. Ressek is suicidal? Have the Arena fights broken him
this badly?
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Suicidal Ressek?

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
"Fight it, Ressek. Don't let them break you- don't give up hope so close to the
end of this nightmare," Shalar urged. A brief spark gave life to Ressek's dead
expression.
"You're right, Shalar. My time is not now, and the end of the tournament draws
near." Ressek's gloom seemed to disappear as he continued on. "I can survive
this- I will make it to the end of this tournament!"
"Good. Now fight me, Ressek. Let us end this battle quickly and cleanly. One
more step towards our freedoms." Shalar backhanded Ressek, but not with enough
force to throw him to the ground, nor enough to draw blood. Ressek look both
shocked and understanding at the same time, a strange combination of emotions
for anyone- on Ressek, the expression looked downright weird.
"Indeed. I have a much-needed rest to earn, and a trip home to make. I do not
want to die here." Ressek lashed out, kicking hard into Shalar's midsection.
Shalar stumbled back, barely catching himself. The crowd cheered- this was what
they wanted to see. Blows and bloodshed. And Shalar was determined not to give
them the latter.
Regaining his balance, he spun, lashing out with his tail the same way he had
against Johnathan, though with less force. Ressek's head snapped back as the
heavy tail-blade connected with his cheekbone, though the hook did not bite in
and draw blood as it had with Talis.
Shalar walked cautiously to where Ressek stood, shaking his head to clear it.
"Had enough, Great Survivor?" Shalar asked.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Great Survivor

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
"They're not convinced," Ressek said, nodding towards the crowd. "They won't be
until one of us is unconcious."
"You mean-"
"Throw me into that wall. This ends now." Ressek winced knowing what he asked of
Shalar.
Uncertainly, but with a speed that amazed Ressek, Shalar had picked him up. The
sharp hooks on his claws dug into Ressek's back, but he ignored the pain,
knowing what was to come next.
With a mighty heave, Shalar threw Ressek towards the wall. He shielded his head,
which was sore enough from the earlier blows, but struck the wall evenly, and
with little pain. Sighing happily, he let himself collapse, relishing what
slight rest the appearance of unconciousness would allow him.
Above him on the terrace, the Arena master growled an obscenity and left his
post above the battlefield.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Ressek Takes the Fall

choices: The next day (This is boring- get on w/it!)
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
"Ressek, good news. The Arena fights are being postponed a day." Shalar stood in
the doorway of Ressek's barracks room. Ressek himself sprawled languidly on the
lower bunk. Siph was no where to be found- likely causing trouble somewhere in
the armory. "The Arena master has determined that all fighters need a holiday,
and we get a whole day to rest up."
Ressek smiled. "This is good news indeed. Even surviving my fights has become a
challenge of late- except yours, of course." He stared at the underside of the
top bunk, frowning. "Though I despise the pity that goes with it."
"I don't pity you Ressek, though I wonder if I should occasionally."
"Good. I wonder," Ressek said, lost in thought, "if a rest was the only reason
we have been given a break, though."

"I don't care how long it takes! You will find out what Shalar wants, and you
will bring it here!" The Arena master paced in front of his guard Captains.
"Sir, I believe that is a man called Kane. From what I have heard, he was the
same man who sold Ryan to you," one of them spoke up.
"Jordan, are these mere rumors, or have you heard something worthwhile?" The
Arena master fixed him with a stare that would freeze fire, it was so cold.
"David Talis spoke of it in the infirmary. Another twist- it seems Kane and
David are related somehow, as is Ryan." Jordan's brow furrowed as he tried to
remember something. "Sir, wasn't it Ryan who killed Harac years ago?"
"No matter. If Shalar wants Kane, then we shall find this Kane. I will get at
least one decent fight out of him before Calarith shreds him."
"But sir-"
"Go! You will arrest this Kane, and he will be brought here for the
fights!" If I can't kill Shalar, perhaps I can use blind emotions to trap
him, and he will get himself killed. And if there was one thing the Arena's
owner knew, it was the effect of blind emotions. One way or another, I will
see him dead.

Shalar walked along the cool corridors of the Arena, despising his virtual
imprisonment but welcoming the prospect of a whole day without fights. After
all, his next would be with Ryan, and he had no wish to fight the Catalyst
swordsman tired. Not that I should be fighting him. I should've left when I
had the chance. Now that I know it was Kane, and not David, I ought to
say I should never have come here at all. Still, Shalar felt he had
fulfilled some purpose by entering the Arena, even if it was not truly what he
sought. Life has its twists...
He paused at a window, looking out into the forest beyond these walls, wondering
how far away Kane had gotten, and how much further he would be before Shalar
could catch and kill him. Too far from here, that is certain. A noise
below caused him to peer out.
Below, several Arena guards were riding out into the forest. Not a hunting
party- they would not send guards for a hunting party. Perhaps a noble, coming
to witness the final matches?
Shalar shrugged, and left the window in favor of the mess hall. Once again,
Arena matters had found him elsewhere while the meals were served, and he was
determined not to miss lunch. Not that the food is good, but we all need to
eat, don't we?
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Respite

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
"Guards, you say? You're sure they weren't hunters?"
Shalar nodded. "I've seen the Arena's trappers and hunters- and they need
neither horses nor chain-mail. These were definitely Arena soldiers."
Tyger stared hard at her meal. "I don't like it. I'm not sure why, but I know it
has something to do with you. I'll be damned if I know what, though."
"Or," said Ressek, joining them, "it could simply be as Shalar suggested- escort
for a noble who wants to see the last fights."
Tyger gave him a look. "Why would a noble not have his own guards?"
"Who's to say he doesn't? Maybe it was just a formality."
"I still don't like it. Nothing good will come of this, trust me."

Evening found Shalar once again at the window. By now, the tale of the soldiers
leaving had expanded itself into several wild rumors, including one particularly
wild tale that had the Arena declaring itself a kingdom unto its own and sending
an army to hold its new borders. Shalar had just laughed when he heard that.
The Arena master is certainly not the type who could handle the affairs of a
kingdom. I'm not sure how he manages to keep the Arena running.
Though the sun sank slowly, for Shalar it seemed too quick as it disappeared
beyond the horizon. All too soon, I will have to face Ryan, and then Siph. If
all goes well, the day after tomorrow I will face Calarith. Shalar clicked
his claws together anxiously. I can only pray that I survive that. Even my
"wild talent" might not be enough- and Aumer knows I'll need all the help I can
get.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Anxiousness

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
It was early morning, and a coolness still lingered in the stones when Shalar strode into the Arena. He saw Ryan at the far end, doing something with his sword, but paid little notice. His attention was fixed on the Arena master. There is something very familiar about that man. He is not Kane, of that I'm sure. But I know I have seen him before.

"Arena warden, why do you persist in trying to kill Shalar? He will bear up under any pressure you give him, and throw it back in your face more often than not." Calarith chuckled, the rumbling sound reminiscent of an earthquake. "Quite amusing from my perspective, of course."
"I know that," the Arena master hissed. "Must you keep reminding me of it?"
"Watch your tone with me, Jarred. I am not one of those petty fools to be ordered around by you."
"You will never use my name, Calarith. Exile was the only choice if I wished to stay alive. The Romarcs would have me killed, otherwise. Even now, they do not know I live."
"In your temper, you give away too much, Jarred. Now I know that I need only fly to the Romarc kingdom, and inform them of your location. Save myself the trouble of dirtying my claws with your blood." Before the Arena master could answer, Calarith was gone, flying out into the scrub-woods for breakfast.
"Damn dragons. One day, I will find a way to have him killed as well." Muttering oaths to himself, Jarred walked to the edge of his terrace and announced the fighters.

Shalar's eyes widened as he heard Ryan's title announced.
"Why does he call you Michael Ryan?"
"That is Jarred. I do not wish him to know that I am a Romarc- he was involved with the 18-year war against my father's kingdom. Soon, he will pay for it." Ryan unsheathed his sword leveling it at Shalar. "I will try not to kill you, but Kane is mine, Shalar, and I will not let you take my vengeance from me."
"It was you who killed Harac, Ryan. You plan to kill Jarred as well. Is that not enough vengeance?"
"He will take my family from me. There is never enough vengeance for that."
"He took my brother as well. You are not the only one he has hurt, Ryan."
The red flag dropped, landing on the ground in a puff of dust.
"Then we shall see now who reaches him first," Ryan said, his eyes beginning to glow softly.
This is going to be one hellish fight, Shalar realized. An epic battle- something the Arena master has been wanting for some time...
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Epic Battle

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Shalar lashed out quickly, clawing the air before Ryan, but the swordsman jumped back quickly, parrying the blow before charging back in. His sword came up in an overhand stroke that Shalar narrowly blocked, and lashed out with his tail.
Ryan's sword reacted in an instant, practically bouncing off Shalar's upraised claws and diving point-first towards the ground. The second Shalar's tail was blocked, the blade again shot up. Before Shalar knew what was happening, the sword was slashing through the air towards his face.
Having no other choice, Shalar raised his left arm, barely deflecting the blow before it reached him. Shalar's head snapped to the side as the sword skipped off his large head-blade, narrowly missing his face. Turning with the force, Shalar spun, landing a hard blow to Ryan's side with his tail.
Again, the sword came around. Too late to block the blow, Ryan instead aimed for Shalar's tail. A deep slice in his tail welled up with amber blood, spraying the ground as Shalar finished his turn. So far, Ryan has had the better of this exchange. I must blood him, or I will die quickly at his sword. Regardless of what he said.

"I think perhaps I have finally found a match for that damn creature. But there's something odd about Michael." Jarred watched carefully as Ryan and Shalar went at it, blow for blow, block for parry. "He fights like a demon- like a..." Jarred's mind reeled, refusing to contemplate what his mouth had been about to say. "No, he can't be a Romarc. His eyes are all wrong."
"I'm sorry, sir- were you talking to me?" a nearby guard asked.
"No. Tell me, what do they call Michael in the barracks?"
"They call him Ryan, sir."
"Not Michael, or Michael Ryan? Just Ryan?"
"Yes sir."
Jarred swore. "No, it can't be. He died in the 18-year war. As did his parents..." There's no way you can be Ryan Lee Romarc! He's dead- isn't he?!?

Below, Shalar and Ryan broke apart, breathing heavily. Shalar stole a glance at the Arena master, but his attention was suddenly captivated by the semi-familiar man.
"Ryan, look at our Arena master. There's something funny there," the bladed creature panted.
"What are you..." Ryan's question died on his lips as he glanced at Jarred. "He thinks he knows who I am. I hope for my sake and his that he dismisses it."
"And why would you want that?" Shalar asked, turning back to Ryan.
"Because I will have no hope of leaving if that man knows I am Ryan Lee Romarc!"
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: "Michael Ryan" Lee Romarc

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Ryan stared hard at Shalar. "Keep fighting- the less he suspects, the better. Jarred may have been exiled, but he is still dangerous. A few of these guards are likely to be remenants of Harac's armies."
Shalar was still absorbing that information when Ryan again came at him, sword raised. Quickly, Shalar deflected the blow, the steel blade sparking off Shalar's bronze claws. Whirling, Ryan brought the blade back around. Too late, Shalar raised his arms to block it. The sword's edge bit deep into his arm, drawing another line of blood from Shalar. Wincing, Shalar kicked out. His long foot-claws smashed into Ryan's knee, drawing twin lines of blood from the swordsman. Ryan stepped back carefully, but Shalar pressed his advantage. His right arms and elbow blade struck out at Ryan, who could not defend himself from all three at once. The swipe at his face was blocked, but the single elbow blade drew a ragged gash across his chest, the lower arm digging into his already injured leg. Ryan pushed the pain from his mind, then fought back. One blade seemed like many to Shalar, who was rapidly backed up by Ryan's vicious counterattacks. Everywhere, the sword seemed to come at him, only barely being parried in time, before it would reappear in another location, seeking his flesh.
His back against the wall, Shalar leaned into the cool stones and kicked out with both his feet. The claws dug into Ryan's thick shoulders, knocking him backwards to the ground.
I hope I have magic left- I will need it now.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Hard Pressed

choices: Shalar attempts to use his magic
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Slowly, still trying to keep up with Ryan's attack, Shalar reached into the earth. Come, was all the voices said this time and Shalar obeyed. Once again he went deeper and deeper, then he found it.
He had been thinking about his power and had an idea of how he could use it, he whispered a prayer to Aumer, then called the golden power to him.
Ryan hesitated when he saw the light, but only for a moment. Now, while he's distracted he thought to himself and swung his sword again. The force the blow was well-aimed and would have disabled Shalar and ended the fight, if it had connected. Suddenly the blade rebounded and all the arena stared in amazement at the amber net that had risen from the ground to surround Shalar.

"Damn, damn, damn." the arena master cursed softly but vehemently, "He shouldn't be able to do that. I'm no mage, but even I know that's not nearly as easy as he's making it look. Where in the six hells did he learn to do that?"
The guards shifted uneasily, recognizing the arena master's mood for what it was and becoming decidedly uneasy. Then, the man forced himself to relax. No matter, he'll still die.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: What the...?

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Shalar focused hard, trying to pry open his "stone door" even wider. Magic flooded him, his blades crackling with unused energy. With a sudden surge, his protective net brightened, then, as before in his fight with Johnathan, a ripple of gold light raced across the ground towards Ryan. A lump of earth followed it closely, as if a fast mole were chasing the magic. A small dust cloud rose from the lump of earth as it reached out towards Ryan.
Then Ryan's eyes glowed bright.
"Stop," he commanded the light. To the surprise of everyone, the light halted in front of him. Cracks in the ground told the story of a magic seconds away from breaking loose, but the end of that story would go untold. With the finality of an executioner, Ryan drove his blade into the earth, right into the heart of Shalar's magic. A golden flare of light shot from the hole, then the whole Arena shook. A ripple of fire raced back down the trail of magic, blasting dirt high into the air as it consumed the tunnel of earth. Dust, smoke, fire, and light all retreated towards Shalar, standing in his golden net.
"Perhaps. But you are wrong. He is a Catalyst, and I don't envy you discovering that when you fight." Tyger's words echoed in Shalar's mind- then the stone door that held his magic slammed shut, and everything went dark.

The instant before the backfiring magic reached him, Shalar's shield dropped. The ground beneath him erupted, flinging him back into the wall of the Arena.
"Finish him, Ryan," the Arena master commanded. "Kill him now."
"Like hell I will, Jared." Ryan stared hard at the man, still one of the most hated men in the Romarc kingdom. But we're not in the Romarc kingdom, and I must remember that. Here, that bastard holds sway.

Shalar's conciousness trickled back slowly. The first thing he saw was the Arena master practically falling off the terrace as he leaned out, staring hard at something in the middle of the battlegrounds. As he raised his head, a wash of dizziness came over him, but he fought it aside and looked ahead. Ryan stood in the center of the grounds, staring back at Jared.
"Ryan...Ryan Lee Romarc!" Jared stuttered. "But h-how? How did you survive? You fell off that cliff three years ago!"
"We Romarcs are a tough breed. Haven't you learned that yet, Jared?"
"Your mother and father weren't so sturdy. I hear tell Kane killed them with ease."
"You heard wrong. And Jared," Ryan said, his eyes narrowing, "I told Harac we were tough years ago, just before I killed him. He hadn't learned that, either."
Shalar sat up slowly, carefully rising to his feet. "Ryan," he croaked, then coughed and recovered his voice. "Ryan, forget him. Let us finish this fight. Then whoever loses can call him out. At least one of us can have our vengeance early."
Ryan looked shocked. "You would be satisfied with Jared's death though Kane still lives?"
"You have prior claim on him. If you cannot catch him, I will chase him to the ends of the earth and beyond, but I give you first shot at him."
"Very well, Shalar."
Bronze blade met steel one over the center of the Arena, while Jared looked on in fury. "Let us finish this bout, so that we can finish our quests."
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: A Second Revelation

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
With a shower of silver and gold sparks, Ryan and Shalar drew back their blades.
"One thing is certain, Jared," Shalar called out, still facing Ryan. "One of us will kill you."

"This is not happening...Ryan died falling from that cliff!" Jared turned to the highest terrace, at the east end of the Arena. "Calarith, call him out. Kill him."
"You are a fool, Jared. I will do no such thing," Calarith rumbled back. "They will fight each other, and if they are strong enough, they will kill you and Kane as well." Calarith turned back to the fight, watching intently as Shalar fended off Ryan's sword, then being countered as Ryan defended himself.

Shalar struck at Ryan again, his left arm cannoning out. Too late, Ryan moved to block it, but only drew sparks from the strangely curved shoulder blade as Shalar's claws hit him, spinning him to the ground. A swift kick rolled Romarc another few feet.
Painfully, Ryan stood again, bringing his sword up. Carefully, he approached Shalar, clearly favoring his right leg- the same one to bear earlier damage. Still, that should not bother someone like Ryan so badly. As he said, the Romarcs are a tough breed. Whatever the reason, Ryan was attacking mainly from the left foot. However, the attacks lacked the power and agility of his earlier fighting, and was unable to block the backhand that smashed into his jaw, spinning him yet again to the ground. He made as if to rise, but sank back down on one knee, staring sadly at the ground.
"This fight is over, Shalar. You have won."
"Thinking like that will certainly make it so, Ryan," Shalar said in confusion.
"You wish to continue until death, Shalar? I know Romarcs do not give up easily, and admit even less freely when they are beaten, but I cannot win this fight- not without a cost to myself that I am unwilling to pay." Ryan looked up at Shalar, who was momentarily taken aback by the emptiness that had consumed Ryan's expression.
He truly is a broken hero, Shalar thought, respect and pity leaking out over his face.
"Find him Shalar. Find Kane and kill him- before he kills my family. They're all I have left in this world." Ryan reached out, grasping one of the long bronze claws Shalar held to him. "Kill him for me, as well as Rievus. And for all the others who were lost in that war."
Shalar bowed his head and pulled Ryan to his feet.
"I will indeed. For everyone."
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Broken Hero

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content: Knowing he has but one fight to go before the days of endless combat against his friends are finished Shalar returned to his room to rest. Lying on the bunk his eyes closed amber light bathing the room, Shalar heard the quiet patter of small feet coming through the door of his room, he sat up surprised I didn't think they allowed children into the arena passages he thought just before his eyes caught sight of a strange creature three feet high, purple with small wings and wicked looking horns atop its thin head, swishing its seemingly overlong tail the creature peered up at him and said 'Hi, I'm Siph.' Shalar was surprisd by this revelation, he had not seen Siph fight or in the passages of the arena even in passing, all he had known was that he was a demon. Shalar had been expecting something more like the creature Jonathon had turned into, though maybe not so large and this funny looking monster was not at all what he had in mind. Still it would not do to be impolite and he was curious as to what the demon wished of him. Shalar smiled 'Come in,' he said making room on the bunk, 'Take a seat.' Siph pattered across to Shalar and plopped down on the bunk, the little demon looked up at him a smile crossing his lips revealing small sharp teeth. 'I have a proposition for you Shalar, I'll get straight to the point, I am fighting you next and I know you just want to leave, well I don't I want to win so I propose this we put on a show then you surrender, hmm. That way I have won all my fights and you have lost one, I get to fight Calarith and you get to leave without facing the dragon, what do you say? I don't want to hurt you and if we go all out I think I would have to kill you to win,' the demons tone turned from light to suddenly menacing 'and believe me Shalar if I have to I will kill you to win.'
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: An offer

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
"Siph, the Arena does not work like that. They will not simply let me leave if I have been defeated. Now excuse me, I have some questions for Ryan." Shalar stood and walked past Siph. The little demon scowled after him.

Out in the corridor, Shalar wondered which way Ryan would be found. The infirmary? No, he wasn't there when I was getting patched up, and he won't be there now, I'm sure of it. As he expected, he spotted Ryan at a table in the mess hall, and paused only long enough at the line to grab two cups of ale. He brought both over to where Ryan sat, setting one in front of the Catalyst.
"So, you did fall off that cliff, and in the process, you hurt your leg?"
Ryan nodded. "I had to use a cane for a year afterwards, and it remains one of my weak points." Shalar peered over his cup, giving Ryan a questioning look. "My family would be another."
"Ah," Shalar said softly, and finished the last of his ale. "Where do you think Kane is now?"
"Likely, he's about two thirds of the way to port- just rounding rocky coast of the mountains. Luckily, his ship will have to bend its course far out to sea to miss those spires. I've heard tell of ships a good two miles out still being snagged on undersea mountains."
Shalar blinked, showering their area of the mess hall with a flash of light. An idea occurred to him, but am I strong enough to pull it off? I havent' had enough practice with these new magics yet, but if that infirmary orderly was correct, and my magic does stem from an earth element... He let the thought trail off- it would bear study later, but he had a match with Siph very soon, and if anything, it would be more difficult than his fight with Ryan.
"How did you stop my magic the way you did, Ryan?" Shalar asked instead.
"Catalyst secrets, my friend," Ryan said smugly, and finished his own drink before leaving the mess hall. "I wish you luck against Siph," he called back, then disappeared down the corridors.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Catalyst Secrets

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Siph stood waiting at the far end of the Arena's grounds, measuring Shalar up even as he walked in. "I can only hope your death is not necessary, Siph," Shalar said, loudly enough that everyone could hear him, but not loud enough to be shouting.
"An I tol' you, Shala. I only killa if I haff to." Siph's lisp was even more apparent in the silence of the Arena, but that was a calm before the storm- a storm Shalar knew would break with all the fury of hell and earth.
I can only pray that earth wins this one.
Though Siph's magic was very powerful, it was in short supply. His main advantage was agility- lightning quickness, and a sharp tongue. I'm not sure if having Siph sound like a three-year old is better or worse, though. Is it more or less insulting to be taunted by a child? Either way, Shalar was sure he would find out soon.
As if to herald the storm's coming, the Arena master walked stiffly to his terrace, bearing the red cloth. The expression on his face would've rivaled any summer squall for storm-like qualities. His mood seemed to blacken everything around him, as though he radiated darkness the way the sun did light. He did not announce anything of Shalar or Siph, but merely declared this to be the last fight of the tournament before the winner faced Calarith for Champion, and dropped the cloth.
The storm broke.
Not wasting any time, Siph raced for Shalar, desperate to make the first move and wound him early. With the short curved horns sprouting from all over Siph, Shalar knew that was indeed a very real threat. With a final leap, Siph shot off the ground, aiming for Shalar.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Storm Breaks

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Shalar saw the demon leave the ground and knew how vulnerable he would be in the air- unable to change his path in any way. With the fastest spin he could manage, Shalar pivoted on his left foot, bringing his tail around in a fierce blow that swatted Siph from the air in an instant, turning him at right angles to his former direction.
Siph was tough, though. He hit the dirt and was on his feet again before Shalar finished his spin.
Shalar expected Siph to leap at him again, but instead Siph just stood a few feet away, smirking at him.
"Nith, Shala, but you won't beat me that eathily."
Shalar was about to ask the demon what he meant when the earth below him rumbled. Glowing red cracks spread out below him, widening as the earth shattered. Fire leaked out between the rifts, sending tendrils of smoke up into Shalar's face as they lifted skyward. Oh no! Shalar thought, and flung himself off that patch of ground. An instant later, a tower of flame ripped through the ground, showering both Siph and Shalar with burning dust and ash. Seeing that Shalar had escaped that bit of magic, Siph released his hold on the column. Instantly, the whole flaming mess collapsed in a shower of fire that drenched everything in its heat. Shalar hissed as the demon's magic burned his back and tail, but resisted the urge to cry out. The cascade ended, but he did not even have the chance to straighten himself before Siph was on him.
The demon's claws tore at him, undoing what the healer mages had accomplished after his fight with Ryan, and opening new wounds in the process. Whatever things may be said about Siph's appearance, Shalar thought briefly, harmless isn't one of them. He lashed out with his claws, but only succeeded in opening his chest to another wound. This has to stop. Now!
Shalar brought his tail around, knowing Siph would automatically dodge it, and swept his claws together. The pincer movement worked, and Siph found himself pinned between Shalar's large claws. For a moment, the demon struggled uselessly, then stopped his thrashing.
But if Shalar thought that was a sign of surrender, he was making a deadly mistake.
Siph's eyes flared a bright red, throwing bloody reflections off Shalar's bronze blades. A second later, the demon's entire body became a bonfire, and Shalar was forced to let go or be incinerated.
Thinking quickly, Shalar leapt backwards, at the same time flinging his blazing enemy at the far side of the Arena. Siph struck the ground a good twenty yards away, rolling briefly before halting in a cloud of dust. The flames went out.
Shalar landed nimbly at his own end of the battlefield. This is it. It ends now, one way or the other.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: All Fired Up

choices: Shalar rests before his last fight
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Shalar knew Siph would not stay down long, and would be impossible to hit once
he stood up. I've got to use it now. I'll not get a better chance.
Reaching inside once again, Shalar pulled the door open, the feel of
stone on stone causing him to grit his teeth.
The magic flowed out, welling up with golden light in the ground beneath him.
Across the Arena, Siph stirred, preparing to get up and attack again. Shalar
knew he didn't have much time, and pulled harder on the magic gathering under
him. The door opened wider, spilling its energies across the dusty ground.
Siph stood up.
Now. Now, or never, Shalar demanded of himself, and the gold light
reached out, a tunnel buried under the dusty floor. A ridge rose up where the
magic sped along, its gold light bleeding through the layers of dirt.
Siph turned.
The magic raced faster, the tunnel flinging dirt into the air as it displaced
earth. With an explosion of dust and light, Shalar's power broke free of the
earth. Like a giant squid, the magic wrapped itself around Siph, coiling in gold
ribbons around the demon's body.
Siph had no time to think, no time to do anything except squeak briefly before
the magics lifted him off his feet and pulled him under. The ground swallowed
him whole, the rift sealing itself behind him in a flash of light.
A silence fell on the Arena, and in that silence, Shalar heard one voice,
whispered at first but growing louder.
"No...no, nooo!!!" Ressek was on his feet, screaming in dispair, but Siph
was already gone. With one leap, he cleared the walls of his terrace and landed,
thirty feet below, in the Arena. He kicked Shalar hard, driving the bladed
creature onto his back. Ressek put his foot over Shalar's throat and growled,
"You promised you wouldn't kill him."
"I didn't. Siph is safe, returned to the hell he came from."
Ressek pressed down, causing Shalar to gurgle. "I should kill you now."
"I'm sure it would please Jared to no end if you did, Ressek. Siph is fine,
though probably a bit shaken up from his short trip."
"How can you say he is fine? You've just sent him to the underworld!"
"He is a demon- he belongs there."
Slowly, Ressek released Shalar from the ground. "He is unhurt, you say?"
"Except for what harm came to him in the fight here." Shalar dusted himself off,
pointedly ignoring the eager expression on the Arena master's face, and the
disgusted, hate-filled one that replaced it as Ressek let him up. "You wish to
go after him, don't you?"
"Siph and I have been friends for a long time, Shalar. Even if he came from
hell, he no longer belongs there."
Shalar blinked, gold light flashing in the shadow of the Arena's walls. "Take
care, Ressek. A demon may belong in hell, but even they have a hard time there."
With those parting words, he left the Arena's bowl. Soon after, Ressek
followed.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Going Home

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
"Shalar, if you thought fighting Ryan and Siph was difficult, Calarith will be a
nightmare. How do you expect to defeat a fully-grown dragon?" Tyger asked.
"The same way he defeated everyone else, Tyger. One part skill, two parts luck."
Ryan shrugged, still somewhat surprised that Tyger had not objected strongly to
his presence in this room. After all, half of it was hers. I wonder- how
close are Shalar and Tyger? Ryan shook his head. Even if the thought wasn't
as rediculous as it sounded, it was still something he didn't want to
consider.
"Ryan, I'm more puzzled about how you plan to kill Jared. He surrounds himself
with guards day and night, and you know he won't let you anywhere near him, now
that he knows who you are."
"True enough, but the guards are fools compared to any true soldier- believe me,
I've had 18 years of fighting to teach me that. Besides," he said sadly,
glancing at Tyger, "I spent an early portion of my life as a mindless destroyer.
No guards, and certainly not Jared, will give me much trouble."
Tyger glared daggers at Ryan, but she knew the man who sat with them in the
barracks now was not the same as the servant of death who had kiled her entire
clan. "I'm sure you'll make it quick," she said acidly. Knowing he was not
himself was one thing- forgiving him for the destruction he had done was
another.
"And what of you, Ressek?" Shalar asked, trying to divert the subject.
"I will go after Siph. I told you- he does not belong in the underworld anymore.
Hell is no longer his home." The fact that Shalar had not killed Siph was likely
the only thing that kept Ressek from crushing his throat in the Arena earlier.
It would be a long time yet before Ressek could forgive Shalar.
"You know I would go with you, if I did not have to hunt and kill Kane first."
"Find me when you are done- I am sure I'll need the help," the lizard said
blandly. Clearly, he did not relish the prospect of chasing after Siph, though
he knew he had to.
"Which reminds me, Shalar- how do you plan on catching up with Kane?"
asked Ryan. "He's likely to be past the mountains by now, or at least passing
them."
"Do not worry for your family, Ryan. I assure you, whatever happens out there,
your family will be kept safe."
"Don't make promises you can't keep, Shalar," Tyger said. "That's a hard lesson
to learn from experience, believe me."
Shalar's reply was cut short by the arrival of an orderly.
"It is time, Shalar. Champion Calarith awaits."
"Oh hell," was all he said in return. Silently, Shalar in the lead, the four
left the room.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: It Is Time

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
The stands had always been full before, but on this occasion, they were packed.
Everyone within miles of the Arena had come to see who, if anyone, could defeat
the dragon that had arrived years ago to dominate the fights. Always before, the
result was the same- the dragon had torn them apart, be it mage, swordsman, or
demon. But this time, they had something new- a creature most had not seen
before, and one to which humans had yet to place a name other than his own-
Shalar. Those who had seen his premature ending with Krath said he was vicious.
Those who booed as he let Sarah walk away untouched said he was compassionate.
Not one had a true idea of who he was.
The sun had just passed noon, hanging high in the sky, when Shalar entered the
Arena for the last time. This is it- the big finish. The one fight I've been
dreading since the day I got here. The one fight, Shalar knew, that he had
almost no chance of winning.
My magics, powerful though they are, would be batted aside in an instant if
Calarith decides to unleash his own powers. True Dragon magics are ancient far
beyond mine- even Ryan's Catalyst abilities would be tested to the limit.
Though, Shalar admitted to himself, a Catalyst had very little in the way of
true attacking magic.
A shadow passed over the Arena. Calarith had arrived.

"Our current Champion of the Arena, Calarith!" Jared shouted. Finally seeing
someone or something that would be able to kill Shalar buoyed his spirits, and
it had been long indeed that such an occurrance had done that for him.
The crowd roared with approval, but the sound was hollow- supportive but
fearful. They are tired of the Champion Dragon. They wish for a new hero.
The thought soured the joy Jared had felt moments earlier, but he forced himself
to continue.
"And the challenger to our Great Dragon, Shalar!" He made his voice as full of
contempt as he could, trying to sway the feelings of the spectators against the
bladed creature. The attempt failed miserably.

Calarith landed in a swirl of dust that stirred the fleshy tassles on his wings
and headfins. No triumphant roar, no showy gout of flame. He relished the fight,
the fresh challenge. Tournaments lasted but a few days- however, months passed
between these sessions as the new competitors worked their way up the chain of
pit-fights outside the Arena's walls. And Calarith was tired of waiting.
"I have waited long for a challenge such as you, bladed one," Calarith rumbled.
The words were not just show- he was as happy for the fight as he was that
Shalar's presence here annoyed the Arena warden.
"And I have long feared it," Shalar admitted. "But they say the first step in
overcoming your problems is admitting you have them. I will overcome you,
dragon. Somehow, I must find a way."
"You are either very brave or very stupid, Shalar, to speak to me in such a
manner."
"I am both, or I would not be here."
Jared cut in, releasing the combatants to each other. "Let this fight
commence!"
The red cloth fluttered in the air, caught a current, and landed square in the
middle of the Arena's bowl. The fight had begun.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Last Battle

choices: Shalar was caught in the flames
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Calarith leapt at Shalar, his huge mass eclipsing the sun. His wings beat the
air, once, twice, sending powerful gusts down on Shalar. Stolidly, Shalar dug
his footclaws in, holding his ground.
The dragon dropped from the sky, landing right in front of him with a rumle that
shook the ground beneath Shalar's feet, the bladed creature losing his footing
at last. Above him, where his head once was, Calarith's tail lashed air. Two
parts luck...
Rolling, Shalar gained his footing again, and pushed off in a might leap that
would have landed him on the dragon's thigh. However, the Champion was big, not
clumsy, and pulled back quickly as he saw Shalar leap at him. The bladed one
landed instead on Calarith's knee, latching on with all four sets of his
clawblades.
Calarith growled with pain and kicked out, trying to dislodge the annoying
parasitic grasp. Shalar clung tight and snapped his head to the left. His long
headblade drew a bloody rent in Calarith's tough scales.
The dragon roared and beat his wings furiously, trying to blow Shalar off him,
but the effort failed. Shalar's tail lashed another furrow in Calarith's leg.
Knowing he had to do something before Shalar disabled his leg, he bent over,
snapping his great jaw at the creature clinging to him. Though he could not
actually bite Shalar, the attempt worked. Fearing he would be torn in two by the
Champion's teeth, he released. Immediately, he was flung to the ground as
Calarith again took to the sky, swiftly winging his way towards the other end of
the Arena. Distancing himself from me? But why..? Suddenly, Shalar knew,
and began a mad dash towards the dragon. I was far too close for a dragon's
flame before, but now...
Now was too late. Calarith landed and immediately sprayed the grounds before him
with a line of fire. Dust and ash combined in a smoky fog that hid Shalar's
dashing form for a moment. The line of fire still burned before the dragon.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: In the Line of Fire

choices: Shalar slashes at Calarith some more
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Calarith stared hard into the flames and smoke, but could not see Shalar. For an
instant time froze- Calarith, watching the flames as he had all the other
fights, the spectators holding their breath, hoping Shalar still lived, Jared,
hoping he had died.
"Come on, Shalar," Ryan whispered. The sound seemed lost in the silence and the
crackling flames below. Then all hell broke loose.
Trailing flames from his blades, Shalar broke through the fire. His legs and
tail were a sooty black, but his bronze blades glowed brighter for the contrast.
An image of heroism and determination, he hung in the air a moment, another
second of time stretched out, as he burst out of the flames. Then he was
running, dashing hell-bent for the Champion that stared coolly at him from the
far end of the Arena. Another gout of flame shot out, but Shalar rolled easily,
and the would-be pyre missed him by several feet.
"Damn you, Shalar, hold still!" Calarith demanded, but of course, did not expect
it to be so. I asked for a challenge- it is I who must over come it. Perhaps
I have been getting lazy these past few months.
Shalar was already on his feet again, far too close for any more flames.
Calarith lashed out with his tail, aiming low should Shalar try another roll,
but instead the bladed one leapt high, well over the tail, to land once again on
Calarith's leg. Instead of latching on, however, he dug his hooked claws deep
and began climbing Calarith. Trying to dislodge Shalar, the Champion snapped at
him, but seeing the dragon's head close enough, Shalar leapt from the leg
towards Calarith's face. A look of surprise and respect crossed the dragon's
features before his eyes narrowed and he opened his jaw once more, ready to snap
Shalar from the air.

Second part luck, Shalar thought, and spread his arms wide. The dragon's
maw snapped shut a hair's length from him, and he latched on for dear life.
Damn! How could I have missed? Calarith fumed, tossing his head to
dislodge the bladed leech clinging to his face.
Shalar slashed once with his headblade before releasing his hold. Calarith's
shaking had brought him exactly the opportunity he had hoped for, and he landed
squarely in the middle of the dragon's chest.
"Get off, damn you!" Calarith roared, but Shalar was already climbing again,
making his way over the dragon's winged shoulder to his back.
Perhaps, just perhaps, I stand a better chance against this dragon than I
thought! Shalar dared to hope.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Through the Flames and Up the Dragon

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Calarith felt a twinge of energy behind him. "You fool, Shalar. Like Antaeus,
you cannot call on your power if you cannot reach your source!" In reply, Shalar
clung tighter between the dragon's shoulders and concentrated.
No, I feel it. The door is here, just much further than I thought...
Shalar struggled to reach his stone gateway, but the effort tired him.
Perhaps he is right- I cannot call on the earth if I am not on the earth.
Then he felt it, the energy that was just out of reach...

"Release me, fight as you did before, as an honest warrior!" Calarith demanded
again, and then he felt something twitch- not behind him as he did before, but
below.
"If I cannot reach the earth," Shalar said smugly, "it will reach me."
Gold light pooled beneath Calarith's feet, spreading out until his whole shadow
was erased by the glowing power welling up from the ground.
"Shalar, you fool, you will destroy us both!"
"As Siph was unhurt by his flames, I will be unhurt by my magic."
"Have it your way, then," the dragon said with contempt, and took flight. He was
about to roar with triumph when the ground he vacated blew apart. Gold magic
swelled up, running a thousand ropes out of the ground at him. They chased both
dragon and creature into the sky, tangling around Calarith's tail, then, as he
was pulled down, his legs, waist, and wings. No longer able to fly, the Champion
crashed to earth. Shalar was flung far from the dragon, his concentration
temporarily shattered. The tendrils of magic weakened their grasp...
Calarith was not about to let the opportunity go to waste, and blasted fire at
Shalar's half-blackened form opposite him. The magic weakened more, its hold
losing power with each moment Shalar could not concentrate on his enemy.
Calarith broke free.
"Now, you will feel what a dragon's magic is like, Shalar," Calarith roared. "It
has been long since I have felt need of it, but what little I remember will make
those ropes of yours look like party tricks. Good bye, Shalar."
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Golden Ropes

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
A new power rumbled through the Arena, shaking the stones loose and raining bits
of mortar from the chinks in the walls. Several of the weaker-minded onlookers
screamed in fear. And perhaps they had reason to.
Fire leaked from the walls, running in thin lines to form a circle around
Calarith. Shalar dodged aside as one strand of flame rushed by him on its way to
join the growing bonfire around the dragon. More strands leaked in, fueling the
circle of fire. The floor of the Arena began to look like a fiery spiderweb,
with Calarith in the middle, silently summoning his ancient powers as the
flaming walls rose higher around him. Slowly, a wind stirred, picked up, whirled
around the hollow walls of fire as they grew taller, spinning the flames into a
tornado. The top sealed over Calarith's head, and still the flames grew
higher.
That fire must be fifty, sixty feet high! Shalar thought in amazement.
The top narrowed, and began bending over. Flames spurted backwards, and then the
whole arrangement became clear- a giant dragon's head, formed of fire, on a long
serpentine neck. Calarith roared with triumph from inside the base of the
flames, and two bright white flames flickered to life where the fire-dragon's
eyes would have been.
I've got to do something, now! Before it's too late! Then a thought
tickled the back of Shalar's mind- the same one that he had thought of on
earlier occasions. I have to try, the alternative being a fiery death...
Concentrating, he unleashed the gold tendrils again.
Calarith laughed, his burning white eyes seeing Shalar far below working the
same pathetic magic he had tried earlier. With a roar like all the fires of
hell, the flaming dragon's visage descended on Shalar.
Shalar's magic shot up, wrapping around himself and pulling him under. The
ground sealed above him with a flash of light- instantly lost in the draconic
inferno that crashed down on the spot a split second later.

Calarith stood in the center of the Arena, his flaming web burning out and
disappearing. Small fires burned all over the spot where Shalar once stood.
Flaming bits- all that's left of him. Then the ground rumbled.
The shocked and dismayed looks of the spectators turned to expressions of awe as
the ground where Shalar had disappeared cracked wide open.
Rising from the rift, protected by a crackling sphere of gold lightning, was
Shalar. His eyes snapped open, their gold light disappearing, and fixed on
Calarith.
"No...how is that possible..?" Calarith wondered out loud. A few brave onlookers
chuckled at the dragon's shock, but their laughter was lost in the tension that
burned in the Arena's bowl.
Again, the gold light spread from around Shalar, but instead of pooling beneath
him, it spread out in a ring. As it passed over the earth, it bleached the dirt
to a bone white, leaching all color and energy from the dry soil. Flickers of
gold lightning twitched across the widening circle, their brightness even more
contrasting with the bleached soil. The net around Shalar brightened as well,
flashing occasionally with a discharge of lightning as it struck the soil or
air. One burned a chunk of rock from the Arena's wall. And still, the circle
widened.
"You were wrong, Calarith. The earth is far more ancient and powerful than the
dragons that roamed it in the old days. It gave you your powers, your form, your
life. It supports all creation. And it can take it all back at will."
"Whose will, Shalar? Yours? You will not kill me."
"No, Calarith, I would not. But the earth does not take kindly to those who
boast of being more powerful than their creators."
Calarith's eyes widened in shock, though whether that shock stemmed from being
lectured by someone so small, or from simple fear of his fate he could not say.
It mattered little now.
The earth shook again, rumbling angrily as it thrust tall pillars of stone
through the Arena's floor. Three, four, five- the pillars kept coming,
surrounding Calarith like a cage. He looked around in fear- they were taller
than him! And still they grew, shooting up from the earth like spears thrust
through flesh. The last fell in place, eight in all, and Calarith took the
momentary silence to attempt flight. But then it was Shalar's turn.
The pent-up energy he harbored flew from him in one massive bolt of gold
lightning, splashing over the octet of stone pillars, linking them together with
electric gold fire that danced between the eight columns, then out across the
tops of the stones, forming a gold net, a stone-and-lightning cage that Calarith
dared not touch. The earth rumbled again.
"What will happen," Calarith asked, a tremor in his usually haughty draconian
voice."
"A year of solitary confinement. Very solitary." The ground buckled under
both Calarith and the stones, and Calarith trumpeted in alarm as the whole
assembly sank beneath the ground. "Goodbye, Champion," Shalar said. His words
were soft, but with a power that made them echo from the Arena's highest
terrace- the one Calarith used to occupy.
The color faded back into the ground, restoring the dusty brown of the dirt, or
the hard gray of the stones. The magic faded, the stone portal in Shalar's mind
swinging shut. Gold light showered the ground as he closed his eyes, sinking to
his knees, and with one last glance around, hearing Jared's angry words declare
him Champion of the Arena, he lost himself to unconciousness.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Solitary Confinement

1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
Moments later, Shalar felt himself being pulled upright. "Damn, Shalar. I've
never seen magic like that before," Ryan muttered to him, helping him up.
"How did you..?" Shalar let the question die, seeing the darkness of the staging
area beyond the walls of the battlefield. Somewhere behind him, he knew,
Calarith stood, raging angrily in his subterranean prison.
"How did I what?"
"Nothing. I'm tired. I need to rest," Shalar said weakly.
Ryan just chuckled.

The next few days found Shalar recovering from his fights. The repeated use of
magic had ground him down "to the point of collapsing" as one healer mage had
said. Most of that time, Jared had stayed far away from his new Champion. The
one time he approached Shalar, he found himself pinned to the wall by his
throat. Of course, it had been his own fault for suggesting that Shalar stay to
defend his title while the pit fights resumed outside the Arena.
Most of his waking hours were spent planning with Ryan, plotting a course to
chase Kane down. After testing his theory during the fight with Calarith, he
knew he could gain a lot of ground per day- faster, even, than a ship.
Unfortunately, he would not be able to maintain that pace for more than half a
day.
"You say you can travel through the earth, Shalar? Tunnel your way to Kane?"
"Not to Kane, specifically, but it will let me move faster if I travel
underground."
"I do not understand that, but if you believe so strongly in your newfound
abilities, who am I to say different?"
Shalar shook his head, unwilling to bring up the next subject, but not callous
enough to let it go, either. "Ressek wishes that I transport him the way I sent
Siph. He has no thoughts of how to return to our world, though. I think he hopes
Siph will know the way back."
"There have been times that I wondered how demons entered this world. Should I
meet Ressek again, I should ask him."
"Ask Siph, when I bring him back."
Ryan and Shalar turned to see Ressek and Tyger leaving the shadow of the Arena's
gates.
"What are you two doing out here?" Tyger asked.
"Plotting the downfall of our enemies," Ryan answered. Shalar was not sure if it
was meant as a joke, but it drew a laugh from Tyger.
"And that involves Ressek?"
"Enough. I leave tomorrow- I do not wish to leave you two clawing for each
other's throats when I go."
"Selfish, Shalar, but fair enough," Tyger said. "Some day, Ryan, you and I
will have to settle this matter." She shrugged and sat down with the
rest. "And what of Jared?"
"Ryan has already determined that Jared dies tomorrow night- the night, in fact,
when he is expected to announce with all due ceremony, my new title of
Champion." Shalar grinned. "A fitting end to his unpleasant business here."

The next day dawned bright and clear. The small scrub forest at the Arena's
borders seemed almost as welcoming to Shalar as the forest he had once called
home. And now, it is time to leave yet again. Run as fast as you want, Kane.
You won't escape me now. With one last look back at the Arena towering
behind him, Shalar set out into the morning.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: The Aftermath

choices: Shalar meets up with Ryan in the bunks.
Shalar meets up with Siph in the bunks.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.content:
"I refuse to kill you Ressek. You do not
deserve to die in here." Shalar spoke softly.
Ressek's eyes looked deep into him and for a
few moments, they just stared at each other.

"If I don't die here, I will die else where.
I want you to kill me Shalar. Make the
Arena Master pay." Ressek suddenly brought
his tail around and swiped Shalar's feet out
from under him. Shalar fell hard on his
back, growling to himself.

"I won't kill you Ressek. I can't, not even
to upset the Arena Master. Your life is
worth more to others than that. Siph would
kill me if..."

Ressek attacked Shalar right then, Shalar
fell back, Ressek on top of him, staring down
into his face. "I want Siph to be blinded by
anger, so that he won't fight. He can't win
his next fight, because he will not win
against Calarith. You must defeat him. Do
not kill him, just defeat him."

"So killing you will make him angry enough to
not fight wisely? Ressek, I can beat him
even if..."

"You are a fool Shalar for underestimating
Siph. He is stronger than he is putting on."
Boos and hisses started eminating from the
crowd. Ressek shoved away from Shalar and
turned to gaze. "Defeat him for me." Ressek
snapped and then withdrew a small blade.

Shalar's eyes widened and before he could
think, he held up his own elbow blades.
Shalar then did the unexpected. He jumped
and landed on Shalar. The two tumbled to the
ground yet again. Shalar shook his head to
get his vision back. He found himself
staring into Ressek's eyes. "Defeat him."
Ressek whispered as blood dripped from the
corner of his mouth.

Shalar looked down. His own elbow blades had
stuck themselves into Resseck's stomach.
Panic whipped through him. "No, Ressek, you
do not deserve this." He cried as Ressek's
eye lids started to flutter.

"I deserve what I get." Resseck hoarsely spat
and then his head went limp. Shalar slowly
pulled his blades from Shalar's stomach. He
stood and the crowd cheered. Blood shed,
it's what they wanted.

"Damn you!" He screamed in the direction of
the Arena Master. "Damn you to hell you sick
bastard!" He screamed and with one last
glance at Ressek's dead body, he stormed out,
leaving the memory and the honor of a friend
soaking into the sands of the arena ground,
staining it dark red.
1221122111111111111111111111111111111111.title: Ressek's Fate

12211221111111111111111111111111112.content:
Shalar did not recognize the voice. Instantly, he knew that to be a bad sign- he would know the voices of competitors, for better or worse. No, this had to be an Arena guard.
"Shalar, what are you doi-" The guard was cut off mid-sentence as Shalar backhanded him into the wall. He crumpled to the ground, but the commotion grabbed the attention of some of the gate guards. Damn it, time to move!

"I don't get it, Jordan. I heard the scuffle same as you, but I look and there's naught but a stirr in the dust." Both guards stared in confusion at each other, but their thoughts were soon dumped into blackness. Shalar dropped from the ceiling, carrying the guard he had knocked unconcious. The weight threw both guards to the floor.
The minute Shalar's clawed feet hit the floor, he was dashing for the gate. The guards, who had been expecting Jordan and his companion, stood in a silent stupor, completely taken by surprise as Shalar charged them. At the last second, one of the boldest drew his sword, but it was barely out of the sheath before Shalar was leaping through the air, well over their heads. In seconds, he was past them, heading into the forest.
12211221111111111111111111111111112.title: Freedom!

122112211111111111111111111111111121.content:
Calarith eyed Shalar running for the treeline, and looked wistfully back at the fight below. Ressek was trouncing Elise good, but the shadow-blooded human didn't make it easy.
Brave little one, to escape that way. Though those guards are fools- I shall have words with this blasted Arena master when I next meet him. Calarith threw himself from the terrace, swooping after Shalar. Come to me, bladed one. You'll not escape facing me so easily!

Shalar's legs pumped hard, his long strides carrying him swiftly towards the trees. But as he neared the treeline, a dark shape threw its shadow over him. With the sun at his back, Shalar knew that could mean only one thing- persuit. And a very large one at that. Nearly as big as...a dragon?! "Oh shit, no! Calarith, what are you doing?" Shalar put an extra lunge into his mad dash, but it was no use. The big dragon, Champion of the Arena, landed square in his path, at the very edge of the trees. Shalar slowed himself rapidly, coming to a stop ten meters from the dragon.
"Shalar, you are bold. Such a competitor as you must not be lost to the world before I face you- and face you I shall."
Shalar set his jaw grimly. "Face me, yes. In the Arena, no. My life continues but for one purpose, and the pleasure of your battle is not it. I will fight you now, dragon. And then I will seek out Kane, and kill him."
122112211111111111111111111111111121.title: Showdown

1221122111111111111111111111111111211.content:
Shalar wasted no time, dashing headlong for the great Champion. Calarith whipped
his long, scaled tail out, but at the last second, Shalar rolled, ducking a blow
that would have crushed his chest had it connected. With a mighty leap, he
launched himself on Calarith, digging his claws in at the thickly muscled knee.
The dragon roared in surprise and pain, kicking out to free himself of Shalar.
The bladed creature was flung hard to the ground, rolling for several meters
before coming to rest in a cloud of dust. Damn, I barely touched him. This
will be so much harder than I ever imagined. Shalar picked himself up
painfully, brushing away the dust. Calarith reared back, spreading his tassled
wings wide for balance.
"Shalar, you are a fool. Surrender before your injuries are too severe."
Shalar stared hard at the dragon before him. Calarith, Champion of the Arena,
and more powerful than that bloated Arena master. Aumer, help me!
Shalar's thoughts whispered, and took a step closer to the great dragon.
1221122111111111111111111111111111211.title: "Aumer, help me."

12211221111111111111111111111111112111.content:
Head bowed, he took another step towards Calarith. And another.
"You're a fool, then Shalar. I can only hope I am not forced to kill you." With
that, Calarith kicked out, once again sending Shalar sprawling. Eyes wide with
shock, the dragon looked on as Shalar stood once more, and resumed his measured
stride towards the Champion.
"We fall so that we may stand again," he whispered, repeating his brother's
mantra. "Calarith, my battle is no longer in that stone complex. It is time to
let me go."
"You go only when you win your freedom from me, little one."
"Very well, Dragon. As you wish."
Shalar knew nothing about magic. He had never used it, never possessed
any, that he knew of. But something at his core told him this was the moment to
try. Grimly, he reached inside himself, trying to tug something loose.
Trying to find the tap of magical energy his heart told him was there.
12211221111111111111111111111111112111.title: Desperate Gamble

122112211111111111111111111111111121111.content:
From deep within Shalar, something stirred. New energy coursed through his
veins, his clawblades glowing with a weak golden light. Warily, Calarith took a
step back, feeling the sudden buildup of power in this small creature.

How is this possible? He has no magic, no innate talents. His blades
resist magic! Calarith took another step back, his tail rustling the
fallen leaves and undergrowth at the forest's edge. Within him, a new respect
was rising for Shalar- respect, and fear.

Shalar felt the energy stirring within him. Come, help me! he pleaded
with it, and pulled it up with all his might, drawing up as much as he could.
The golden halo surrounding his blades brightened, and was matched as he closed
his eyes, the phosphorenes adding to the brilliance around him. He focused on
the great dragon before him, pushing the magic out into his bronze clawblades.
Light flared from his four sets of claws, ropes of gold lashing out with
blinding speed.

His amber blood thundering through his head, Shalar sank to his knees. From
somewhere seemingly distant, he heard a dragon bellow in pain and anguish. The
energy was gone, drained away- squandered in a single attack. Behind him, he
could hear the guards catching up. His eyes opened, the gold light fading as his
vision cleared. Calarith lay on his back, wings and scaled chest burnt in
several places. Small fires still burned in the worst of the charred spots, and
several black-rimmed holes dotted the dragon's large wings. Calarith stirred and
groaned again. I've got to move, got to get going...but I'm so tired!
Shalar struggled to his feet, but could only manage a couple halting steps
before falling again. I've overstretched myself. Whatever that magic was, it
couldn't have been Aumer helping me. That came from within. I do have
magic, of some form, and I've drained myself thoroughly of it. So weak...all
this thinking... Shalar did not know when he collapsed to the ground, but
the dust settling back down on him told him that it wasn't more than a minute or
so. Calarith stirred again. I must get up...get away. Move yourself,
Shalar!
122112211111111111111111111111111121111.title: Golden Light

1221122111111111111111111111111111211111.content: "Come on, think Kane," he muttered to himself. He struggled to his feet, then managed to run until he found a nice clump of scrub to hide in. The guards looked for half a day, but to no use, Shalar had escaped.
1221122111111111111111111111111111211111.title: In the clear...sorta

choices: Shalar is returned to the Arena
1221122111111111111111111111111111211111.content:
Roughly three days east, through scrublands and desert, lay the city of Port Cannon. Shalar knew his best bet to find, or catch up with Kane, would be in that city. No sane person would travel back through the desert, mountains, and swamp when they could go by sea. But then again, no sane person would kidnap someone like Ryan and force them into slavery, either.

By the time Shalar neared Port Cannon, he was exhausted. Nights spent crossing the deserts and scrub were icy cold, the days blistering hot. And there was no water or food to be found- Shalar had lost all his supplies in that brief fight with Calarith. Luckily, he could just make out the city in the distance. As he raised his head for a better view, however, a massive shadow loomed over him. He dared not look, knowing what lay behind.
"Did you really think you could escape so easily, Shalar? You will fight in the tournament. There is no escaping it. And because of this, you will die, as per the orders of the Arena Warden." Calarith's gold eyes stared at him. Shalar could well imagine icicles forming at the corners, so cold was the gaze.
1221122111111111111111111111111111211111.title: No Escape

122112211111111111111111111112.content:
Almost as if the gods had heard Shalar's silent plea for an impossible outcome-that Shalar wouldn't have to kill the man who's only crime was relation, a bolt of lightning lanced down and struck David. The man crumpled bonelessly to the ground, only the faint rise and fall of his chest proclaiming that he still lived.

Shalar walked over to the prone body and knelt. "I am not your enemy David. I understand you must protect your kin, but I will have my revenge. I only hope you will stay out of my way when that time comes." He took a blade and carefully drew a cut across David's cheek. Then, he stood and left David to the attendants who were even then coming to take David to the infirmary. Shalar studied his claw and sighed. It was time to leave.
122112211111111111111111111112.title: Divine intervention

1221122111111111111111111111122.content:
His body ached and his vision was blury. All in all, David decided it would be best just to lay there motionless for a while, or at least until his head stopped spinning.
"Ah, you're up." A generic looking woman walked over to his bed.
"What happened? Why didn't Shalar kill me?"
"You were struck by lightning, and" she shrugged "no one knows."
David felt a subtle stinging on his cheek and raised his hand to it, he felt the scab covering the cut Shalar had given him.
The woman noticed, "He gave it to you, don't know why, but it'll leave a nice little scar."
David barely noticed her, all he could think of was-he didn't kill me.
1221122111111111111111111111122.title: Morning, sunshine

12211221111111111111111111111221.content:
It seemed though that he didn't care. Despite what he had told Shalar, he truly cared little of what happened to his nephew. It was simply the idea that Shalar was going around threatening people bent on vengeance. David had seen what it could do to a man, for it had destroyed his brother. He hated to see it happen again to one such as Shalar.

But now there was little he could do about it. David stood, but found himself dizzy. "Where is Shalar?" he asked, brushing off the nurse. It was time that they talked, and David hoped he could make him truly understand. Despite what he hoped, he knew that it would most likely not come true. A man would take too many extreme steps for his revenge. Ryan had suffered for it, as had so many others. Eventually they would learn.

"Shalar is resting up for the next fight." The nurse said, trying to get him to lie down. With one glance from his Canine eyes, she backed down.

"I will go see him then."
12211221111111111111111111111221.title: Pain and Vengeance

122112211111111111111111111112211.content:
Shalar was sitting on his bunk when David found him, he looked up curiously,"Do you still want to kill me?"

"No, I want you to give up the idea of killing Kane though."

"I'm afraid I can't, it's not the only thing I have, but I still have to do it. It's a strange thing, but it's a part of me now."

David sighed,"You will continue with this thing even though you know it means your end? You've seen the others who have been driven by vengeance, you know what has happened to them."

"I wish there was some way I could let it go, but there isn't, I can't rest until I know my brother's ghost can rest in peace. And that won't happen until I bring his murderer to justice."

"Justice? You mean murder." Shalar said nothing, but fixed David with a cold stare. Something in that look made David understand. He thought for a few long moments, the silence seeming to prod him along, "What if I were to tell you there was a way to settle Revius' ghost and not kill Kane? What would you do then?"
122112211111111111111111111112211.title: Decisions, decisions

1221122111111111111111111111122112.content:
"No. Whatever you're hinting at, it changes nothing. I will kill Kane, I just hope you aren't in the way when I do so."

David's jaw clenced, "As you will. I did not want to be your enemy, but you leave me no choice." Deliberately, he turned his back on Shalar and left.
1221122111111111111111111111122112.title: Bad moon rising

12211221111111111111111111111221121.content:
Shalar lay on his bunk, running his conversation with David over and over in his mind, if only it hadn't come to this...His musings were interuppted by the sound of approaching footsteps.

A woman he'd never seen before stepped into his cell escorted by a guard, "Holler if he tries anything you don't like, ma'am, I'll be right outside the door." At her nod, he closed the door behind her.

Shalar considerred his visitor. She was, by anyone's standards, lovely a graceful woman who had the look of a predator about her. He felt his curiousity rise.

After a few moments of seeming to examine the small room, the woman's gaze fell to Shalar, she nodded, "I am Thara."

He shrugged, "So? What are you doing here?"

"It is not unusual for a wealthy woman to pay for a visit to an...arousing champion. You have attracted my interest and I would trust that you are not unwilling?"

"I am not willing to be a whore, my lady. I will not allow you to press this."

She thought about his answer, then a pleased gleam came to her eyes, "I thought as much, but I thought I may as well try."

"I take it that's not the only reason you are here?" Shalar prompted when she showed no sign of leaving.

"Of course not, I have something of a proposition for you..."
12211221111111111111111111111221121.title: An unexpected visit.

122112211111111111111111111112211211.content:
He studied the woman closely, "And what kind of proposition would that be?"

"I offer you freedom in return for your promise to kill my husband."

Although he really did not care what her vendetta against her husband was, the conversation was proving an interesting diversion. "Why do you want your husband dead, my lady?"

"Because he's cruel...and wealthy. You have nothing to lose, might I remind you, I am offering you your freedom and all I ask in return is something that is petty compared to what you will face if you refuse."

Shalar thought, her arguement was sound and he had been planning on escaping. "Can you gaurantee that you can get me out?" Thara nodded solemly. Well, he had nothing to lose.
"Alright, I agree. Who is your husband?"

She smiled and said the one word he had least expected to hear, "Kane."
122112211111111111111111111112211211.title: Two for the price of one

1221122111111111111111111112.content:
The storm Shalar had noticed earlier was moving in rapidly, a cool wind carrying with it the scent of rain was already blowing the dust around the Arena's floor. The light was clouded over, but Shalar had no trouble making out the sword-weilding form of Ryan Lee Romarc entering the other side of the Arena.
"The Arena master was disappointed in Raven and sent you to kill me?" Shalar asked.
"No. He just felt that you didn't deserve to face David." Ryan shook his head in disgust at the upsurge of politics that seemed to be plaguing the Arena of late.
