Not that he cares for the well-being of the Arena, but it is disappointing to see that even straight combat can be ruled by deception. To Ryan, he said simply, "It's a shame we can't run away from it all. Neither one of us are here to fight each other."
Ryan raised an eyebrow, glancing suspiciously at Shalar. "What do you mean?"
"Don't try to hide it, Ryan. I know you're only here because you were forced to be. Tell me, what did the man who brought you here look like?"
"Sandy hair, cold eyes, and the disposition of a sand viper. His name is Kane, the son of Harac." Ryan clenched his fists. "He's after me because it was I who killed his father."
Shalar's eyes flashed as he blinked in shock. "I had suspected, but...That's the same man who lead the attack on the mercenaries. The same man who killed my brother." He turned to Ryan. "I want him dead as much as you, and perhaps moreso. If we help each other get out of here, we'll seek him out together, and put an end to it all." He held out his clawed hooks to Ryan. "Help me, Ryan. Help me bury our ghosts."
1221122111111111111111111112.title: Conspiracy?

choices: They find guards at the top of the wall
12211221111111111111111111121.content:
Ryan stared hard at Shalar. "We'll help each other out of here, but when it comes to Kane, the first one there gets him." Carefully, Ryan clasped Shalar's claws.

"Damn it all, Calarith! He's not fighting Ryan either! They're plotting something, I know it!" The Arena master stared hard at the pair shaking hands in the Arena's bowl.
"That is your concern, not mine. I already told you I will have nothing more to do with the fights outside my own."
"Fine," the master spat, "then I'll deal with it myself."

"Now, in about thirty seconds, that storm will break. We can use the cover to escape."
"Shalar, we're in- oh, those claws of yours. Climbing out, are we?" Ryan shrugged. "As I said, we'll work together until we find Kane. After that, it's first come, first served."
Their plans were cut short as the doors of the Arena burst open, spilling several guards into the battlefield. One of the lead guards brought up his spear, pointing it squarely at them both. "Shalar, Ryan, you will come with us immediately." The commanding tone in his voice left no doubt that he would attack them immediately if they refused.
"When the storm breaks, run for the wall. They can't climb the way I can, and I'll bring you up with me."
"Tyger will be disappointed that she never got to face me," Ryan muttered. The rain broke an instant later, and the pair ran for the wall. Through the driving rain, the Arena guards could barely make out Ryan and Shalar as they climbed up the wall, but did their best to reach the fighters before they could escape.
"My goal was to avenge my brother, Reivus. I thought his killer was here, so I entered," Shalar explained as he pulled himself and Ryan up the slick stones of the Arena's walls.
"But he's not. He's the one who put me here before returning to finish off my family, the way I finished his father." Ryan grunted as he pulled himself up Shalar's wide shoulders. "That was one of the few bright points in my life- driving my sword through Harac's chest."
Shalar merely nodded and climbed faster. Already, he could see the guards below turning back, hoping to reach him at the top of the twenty-foot wall. He blinked, gold phosphorenes glittering on the rain-soaked stones. "They're too late. They won't catch us in time."
12211221111111111111111111121.title: Escape

122112211111111111111111111211.content:
Ryan looked at Shalar, almost unwilling to believe what had happened. That they had not only allied themselves, but had managed to escape...Ryan shook his head and turned to Shalar. "What now?"

"We go east. I think I know where we can find Kane."

Ryan nodded and stood, "Let's go."
122112211111111111111111111211.title: Out and about

1221122111111111111111111112111.content:
The part they hadn't thought of when they decided to go east was that "east" was a long way off. After two days, they had to stop and get some supplies. Conveniently, they spotted a quaint little farming village right along their route.

"Hey," Ryan pointed it out, "we should be able to find some food and better clothes there."

Shalar thought about it, "I don't know. This close to the Arena, word's sure to be out about the two escapees. I think we'd be safer to try and find somewhere where we won't stand out as much."

"Well, they'll mostly be looking for you, due to your...unique looks, but I don't think they'd really notice me as more than a traveler. Besides, I can do a passing bard impression. No matter how dangerous it is, it's less so than going on without any supplies."

"Hmm..."
1221122111111111111111111112111.title: Stomach grumbles

12211221111111111111111111121111.content:
"...I don't like it, but we really don't have any choice." Shalar shook his head, "Don't stay any longer than you absolutely have to, I'll camp by the river."

"Alright. And who knows, I might even be able to learn something about Kane."

"Don't ask too many questions, the less attention you draw to yourself, the better."

Ryan shrugged, "Well, I don't know how well that'll work, I'm going to be a bard, after all."

"Just don't be a problem. If you're not back in three days, I'll assume they killed you and keep going."

"Alright. I'll see you in three days."
12211221111111111111111111121111.title: 'til we meet again

13.content:
Sarah gave Ryan a smile and hopped down from her bunk. She felt bad for the man, he had family who needed him now. Everyone had heard the tales of his heroism in the eighteen year war, but not many knew all of it. He had a sad past, and she knew enough about him to stay out of it. Her brother had been a good friend of Ryan's, until he had died to save him. But she bore no ill will towards Ryan. After all, if her brother had thought so highly of him, then she should too.
"I'm going to look at the fighting roster. I'll catch up with you later, Ryan."
He nodded to her, caught up in his own thoughts. "Yes, good luck."
Sarah strode out into the hallways. Others were already gathered around the roster sheet, though she only recognized a few. She had seen Siph before, as well as Tyger and Shalar. Others she didn't know too well, but she was a little intimidated by the size of Krath.
She tried to push down her fears and scanned the length of the roster. She groaned when she saw who it was she was fighting.
13.title: Sarah's First Fight

choices: They back away to assess the fight
131.content:
"Sarah...You were the last person I ever expected to fight, you know." David stood in the center of the Arena, waiting as she walked up. His sword arm was encased from shoulder to wrist in heavy armor, but the rest of him was lightly armored. Sarah had never seen him in wolf form, but she suspected the armor was specially made to protect him in a transformed state.
"David," she said, nodding. Her voice was flat, but carried no malice with it.
While the Arena master spoke loudly about the start of the fight, Talis leaned close and whispered, "Some greeting! But I promise not to hurt you any more than necessary."
"And I you," she replied, then added, "you pompus ass." She grinned, and winked at him to ease the startled expression on his face. They were still smiling as the red cloth dropped, signaling the beginnings of battle.
131.title: Grins all around

1311.content:
There was a sharp ring as the blades clashed. A roar started from the crowd, encouragements and insults yelled at the two warriors.
Sarah spun out of the dead lock, bringing her sword round in a low sweep to the legs. David jumped, parrying her next thrust, then trying for a slash to her arm. Sarah caught it, and gave the man a smile. David grinned back.
'Let's give the crowd a show,' he said. He stepped away, and stood very still.
The change happened quickly. Sarah saw the smooth transition, as David morphed into his wolf form. The cheering from the people increased.
The David-wolf growled. Sarah prepared herself for the new attack.
1311.title: Wolf.

1312.content:
Sarah backed off too the wall where she had a good veiw of the arena. She noticed everything that might give her an advantage using her theif's eye. Then she watched David to see what he was doing. He raised his sword and looked at her, signalling he was ready to fight. They charged forward.
         At the last moment she raced instead to the side, quickly turning before David recovered himself.
1312.title: The battle begins

135.content:
Sarah groaned and went back to her room, great!
Her roomate was missing and she wanted to talk to someone, how could she fight that, that thing!
She knew she had two options
135.title: Are you sure I have too

14.content:
Ryan shoved the thoughts from his mind and stood up. He needed to check the battle roster to see where he would be, but it didn't really matter that much to him. The killing would start soon. He had almost separated himself from battles, making it a duty. He took no pleasure in it, only did what was necessary to get out. Tyger though, she scared him. She scared him because he recognized her from years ago, before he had changed, before he had left Harac. But that was another story, and one he tried to block out.
He picked up his sword on his way out, not even bothering to close the door.

Tyger strode away from Shalar, angry that she had let him get to her like that. It was true what she'd said. Ryan was a Catalyst, just like the man who'd murdered the rest of her clan. But she had killed him long ago, and soon she would kill Ryan as well.
She rested a clawed hand lightly on the hilt of one of her dirks. She had to win this. She would prove that she was the best, and no one, not Shalar and not Ryan, was going to get in her way.
'Besides.' she thought with a smirk. 'If they try, then I will simply kill them.'

Siph stared at the floor as he walked toward the roster posts. I got Ressek into this, whether I like it or not. I suppose I'll be the one to get him out. As he reached the rosters, he noticed Ryan standing beside him. So many in this fight against their will. Ryan, David, Ressek, Krath...If- no when I defeat Calarith, I'll have them all released. Siph sighed. But that means they must survive the fighting. And with so many determined to kill each other, that's a real problem.

Elise walked back up the stone steps towards the main level. She couldn't shake her anger at Raven, and in part, didn't want to. The little dragonette had caused her a lot of pain and heartache, while she wasn't even sure if he had meant to or not.
It had been only a few years ago, back when she had been but a girl. He had lured her out into the field, squawking excitedly. She had thought she was needed, or that he'd found something.
In truth he had: slavers. They had taken both her and Raven, and she blamed the dragonette for it all. But now was her chance to escape. She would win her match, and in the end, he would die.

Raven stirred excitedly in his cell. The orderlies beyond his bars were holding keys, and that meant food. Then he remembered- the fights begin today. He would have to fight his food, hunt it down and kill it, before he could taste its blood, its flesh.
He stopped pacing and squawked excitedly at the orderlies, who paused in their work to regard him warily.
"That one's gonna be a real fun fight to watch," commented one dryly.
"Fun? It's gonna be a bloodbath, you mark my words. I don't think even Krath is going to stand up to him for very long..." The other orderly chuckled. "Then again, that's not saying much..."
14.title: The First Arena Fighters

141.content:
Ryan walked quickly from the room, heading down the hallway. The cool stone walls felt good, for he knew that it would get much hotter in the day. It was like that in the southern lands, not too mention how far it was from his home. Not that anyone but his wife would miss him. His mother-in-law worried about him constantly, and that he would get Kopri hurt. But she needn't worry about that.

Up ahead other warriors gathered around the roster to see their names. He leaned against a wall and waited patiently. There was no need to push his way foreword.

Tyger walked past him, and paused, narrowing her eyes. "You will die at my hands, human." she said stiffly, before continuing past him. He followed her with feirce eyes, but said nothing.

As the warriors thinned, he walked foreword and glanced at his name on the roster. 'Damn.' he thought, seeing that he was first. And who he was fighting.
141.title: Ryan's First Fight

1411.content:
Tyger would be a difficult fight. He knew she bore hatred towards him, he just tried not to acknowledge it too much. He was used to being hated, it was how he'd spent much of his life.

Well, it didn't matter now. All that mattered was that he win. He had to return to his family, or else they would suffer a painful death.

He turned to the entrance of the Arena, gazing out at the large dustbowl that he was to fight in. He hated it, all of it. They all cheered for him when he came out, when he drew blood, and he hated it. The crowds voice meant nothing to him, except that they enjoyed to watch slaughter and bloodshed, something he had gotten his fill of.

He vaguely heard the Arena Master announcing his fight. With a sigh, he strode out into the center of the Arena, prepared to take on the scarred gargoyle opposite him. She was called Tyger due to all the stripe-like scars covering her leathery gray skin.

"You will die today, human." she hissed, baring her sharp fangs. Ryan was unresponsive to the threat.

"We shall see." was all he said, and then the fight began.
1411.title: Beginning and Threats

14111.content:
Ryan felt the a familiar numbness. It came to him in all battles, sweeping in with a thunderous ferocity that brought both a measure of pleasure and an eerie calm. It was the pleasure that he despised. He told himself that he had no hatred for the creature that stood before him, that he felt nothing as she issued her enraged battle cry and came toward him across the sand covered floor of their battle ground. But he did feel something, and that something was the thing that kept him awake at night. That something brought the nightmares of the fire and the burning and the blood that had encompassed his being so long ago. He had been death's fiercest warrior, slaughtering without pity, without mercy.

That same something made him fear for his family and their fate if he did not win this match and the others after it. He knew well the horror of war, the diseases of the battle engorged mind. He knew that to murder women and children, entire families was nothing for a warrior who had even a small taste of what he was feeling right now.

She came at him with the fury of one depraved. There was something about her movements that lacked caution, even common sense. They were movements inspired by the fury that desperation lent. She hated him. He had recognized that instantly. He had a hazy picture of her and her kind somewhere in the back of his mind, the image smelled of blood and death. The image shamed him. He knew that he had wronged her deeply, somehow, or at least she felt he did.

He pitied her, but he would show her no pity in battle. She had her agonies and he had his, and this is where fate had taken them. There was no mercy, no pity in the arena, and Ryan did not believe in self sacrifice, even if he deserved nothing more than to lay at the ground at her feet in a pool of his own blood.

Not today.

Today he would fight. Today she would die, her wrongs, sadly, unavenged. The lives of his family depended on his survival. He did not dare think on anything else.

She checked herself, got control of her hatred and the slitted yellow eyes of the gargoyle followed him as he moved to circle her. " You will die today murderer of children," she hissed.

She slashed at him suddenly with her tail. Pain exploded in his shoulder. The tough gray-green skin cut like metal, opening his flesh up, exposing his blood and thick white muscle to the sun.

The crowd roared. " First blood," they shouted, frenzied.

She laughed, triumph riding in her yellow eyes.

It was not rage that Ryan felt when he dipped low and came at her suddenly, nor was it a quest for revenge for the scar given, or the humiliating screeching of the crowd at the sight of his blood. He had many scars, from many battles, far too many to count. He cared nothing for what the crowd of blood thirsty hounds seated above them thought. No, it was a simple desire to win that propelled him. The desire to end this battle and begin the next and the next after that until he stood with his foot upon Calirith's bloody, oozing skull.

She slashed at him with the dirks she carried, even as his sword cut across her mid-section and thinly opened the flesh there. Her guts strained against the broken encasement of her flesh. He brought his sword up again, ignoring the pain of the twin wounds she had opened on his chest. He went for her throat, meaning to do her in and be done with it.

She saw him coming, saw his intent and kicked at him with her strong legs and clawed feet. He stumbled backward just a little but it was enought for her to put some distance between them.

Ryan watched her, feeling the blood oozing thinly from his body. Above them, the crowd went mad. His world became the all encompassing howl of their many voices combined. His opponent stepped sideways, shifted in the dirt and sand. She eyed him cautiously, hatefully. Then she howled and came at him again, the dirks crossed at her chest, the tail darted in and out all around him, tearing at his face and head.

She was strong and when she crashed into him it took every ounce of his strength not to fall backwards. Falling would have meant his death and he was not going to die here today. He steadied himself and sent his sword in a slashing arc that connected with her shoulder and took her arm off above the elbow. Black blood rained upwards and clouded his eyes as she screamed and fell to the ground before him.

He barely noticed the agony of the dirk that was stuck, maybe an inch deep, in his right thigh. They had healers and magicians in the arena for such pains. The main thing that a contestant had to do was stay alive, as long as one was breathing then the healers could fix any wound, no matter how bad it was, for the next fight. It made for good business, the people paid more to see their favorite fighter fight again and again and again . . .

He towered over her and she scrambled back in the sand, slashing at him with her tail and the tiny jewel encrusted dirk she held in her one good hand.

" FINISH IT!" the crowd screamed, the crowd shouted, the battle was his.

Ryan . . .
14111.title: Ryan and the gargoyle . . .

choices: Raven swoops in to clean up the mess
141111.content:
*ok, right now i gotta say, this is REALLY good. I'm not adding to it to get a couple o' gift points out of it. Umm...being that I don't know what this is going to be about, be prepared to get really confused*

Quickly, before he made the final strike and finished the damn thing, Ryan prayed. The silence encompassed him and the crowd for a moment...something more than just hate, love and blood bound pair of fighters together...Only Tyger's wheezes could be heard. Although the crowd screemed, their voices dissapeared into nothingness. A lone spire rose from the sun turned blade of Ryan's sword as he prayed for the safety of his worthy opponent in the life beyond death. He opened his eyes, his peace and serinety overtaking Tyger.

She snarled, the killer sound fading to a moan as she lay there, dieing in her own blood....there was something familiar about Tyger...what was it?

A flash...a screem...a dirk shining in the moon light, its deadly light blinding its enemies...what's that feeling? Longing..? Soul Ach..? Love..? No, not any of them. Something so much deeper than the universe is wide.

Ryan felt a tear trickle down his cheek. Tyger closed her eyes, giving in to the pain as her life slowly oozed out her gut. Ryan dropped to his knees beside Tyger, clutching at her paw, "Sarhuekey!!!" What was he saying? That word, it flowed so liquidickly from his toungue like he'd always known it...

...a dirk shining in the moon light, its deadly light blinding its enemies...

The dirk swooshed up to meet Ryan's flesh, pinging lightly upon Ryan's sword as Tyger made one last weak attempt on his life. The weapon hooked around his throught, "If I'm going to die, you will die with me!!!"

A flash...a screem...a dirk shining in the moon light, its deadly light blinding its enemies...Ryan remembered now. So long ago...what had happened why had he forgotten? His true family he had never met. Sarhuekey, the gargoyal who had taken him, protected him...loved him! The rist band on Tyger's paw glittered with black stones, symbolizing her clan. Sarhuekey's had done the same...

Tyger (or rather, Sarhuekey) felt the last of her strength leave her, "At the hands of my only family...or rather X-family..." she spit at Ryan, a little puddle of greenish slime landing on the ring upon his hand.

Ryan glanced down at his only posession of value, a silver ring with encrusted black stones, now covered in gargoyal spit...what had happened? how had he and Sarhuekey been seperated? Why had his 'godmother' turned against him?

Tyger's eyes opened and gazed at Godknowswhat. Her dirk slipped away from Ryan's throught. Whatever her troubles were...they lay unavenged.
141111.title: Sarhuekey?

141112.content:
He raised his blade, the blood rushing through him, demanding that he make the killer blow. Tyger's eyes did not waver from him, they just glared in hatred and unfullfilled vengeance.

"Murderer." she hissed at him. He paused, waiting to hear her reasoning. Many terrible acts had been committed at his hand, there was no denying that. He had murdered before, but that was only to avenge the death of another. All else he claimed in self-defense.
Except for...

"No." he whispered in shock, unbelieving that she could be what he thought she was. He had been raised by a man who'd wanted him to be the perfect killing machine, and had carried out many orders unquestioned.

Including the destruction of a clan of gargoyles.

"Yes." she hissed back, hatred evident in her voice. "You killed them all didn't you, Catalyst? You killed my family, and now you want to finish the job."

In the back of his mind, he could hear the crowds chants, screaming at him to kill her, to let her blood run freely onto the dusty floor. But he couldn't now, not with the knowledge he had. How could he have forgotten so easily? It was true that it had been at least fifteen years since the deed had been done, but all else had lingered in his mind so easily.

"Go ahead and kill me, scum. I will haunt you till you die."
141112.title: Hidden Truths

choices: He fights no more, that day.
1411121.content:
He studied the Gargoyal's burning eyes. She would never forgive him for what he had done. She lived to kill him, that would be changed.

His blade sang as he brought it down with all his might on her thick neck. Blood sprayed as he sliced through her thick hide, severing bone and sinew. Black blood ran like a river as he cut through arteries, her life blood washing over his boots like a tide. The sand was coated in an oily black. Her eyes dimmed as her head rolled over the arena floor. She was dead.

The crowd cheered as one, to his ears it was like one hideous monster screaming it's approval of his actions. He turned in a full circle, glaring at the crowd with his cold, red eyes, wishing every one of them dead. But that he could not do. He could not silence the mob.

He turned and left, blocking out the cheers. Almost wishing he had lost. Those thoughts quickly vacated his head. He swore he would not loose.
1411121.title: One Less Opponent

1411122.content:
His blade lowered. Now he couldn't kill her, not knowing what he did. Other pains and truths haunted him, but he had thought most shut away. Years ago, he had almost died, and it had sent him into a well of despair out of which he had thought there to be no escaping. He had hated the world, but mostly himself, for he thought himself responsible for his parents death. It was only Kopri that had saved him from that, and now her life depended on him escaping from the Arena.

"I cannot kill you." he said, throwing his sword aside. Then he offered her his hand. "I am sorry for what I did to your clan, and to you. I hope you can forgive me."

She stared at the hand, and then at his gray eyes, as if they would hold an answer.
Then she...
1411122.title: Extended hand

14111221.content:
...clasped his hand. "I will never forgive you, Ryan. But this fight is over." With that, she turned. The tip of her tail lashed Ryan across the cheek, as though she had slapped him. He merely stood there, watching his enemy leave.

"So, in the end, you live. And so does Tyger. This was an outcome I never expected." Sarah flopped over on her back, head hanging off the end of the bunk. For her, the whole room suddenly turned upside down. "The next time will likely be different though."
"Next time?" Ryan peered up from his sword, staring at Sarah's upside-down form. "What makes you think there will be a next time?"
"Ryan, you know better. She'll fall behind because of this loss, but will work her way back up. And you know it," she finished, flipping gracefully to the floor.
Ryan merely bent his back and polished the blade harder. "I have enough things to deal with. Tyger's vengeance is the least of them. What happens when Kane finally catches up with my family, Sarah? If the fights continue at this pace, I'll never make it out of here in time."
"Yes you will. I think you'll find some help in that area. 'Ask and you shall recieve' is the phrase I believe..." Her voice trailed off as she made her way down the hall.
"'Ask and you shall recieve'...What am I asking for?" Ryan shrugged at the final cryptic remark and left the barracks room, heading back down to the staging area for his next fight.

"I hear tell it's Shalar on the other end out there. Boy, I don't relish fighting that monster."
"That job is for the fighters like me," Ryan said harshly. "And I have to end it quickly. Time is running out." Without waiting for an answer, he strode into the Arena's bowl. Sure enough, Shalar was on the other end. Something niggled at the back of Ryan's mind. Ask...but ask what? Why is Shalar here...? To fight David? But wait- Shalar knows now that it wasn't David who killed his brother. But if so, then who? Who could he confuse with Harac..? Ryan's eyes widened with shock as he realized the answer. It would be easier to simply fight my way out of here...
Overhead, thunderstorms rumbled. A storm was about to break, and soon.
Do I fight Shalar? Or do I ask his help in escaping this place?
14111221.title: Ask and you shall recieve

141112212.content:
Shalar nodded his head in respect when he saw Ryan. The bladed warrior had no malice in his eyes, but an iron will that could not be shaken. Ryan met his eyes with the same look, his eyes calm and collected. He bore no hatred towards Shalar, but he was willing to do whatever it took to get out of the Arena. His family was depending on him. He would not let them down.

For a moment, his memory drifted back to the last time he'd seen his wife. Kane had taken them hostage, and Ryan had ridden in, willing to do anything to save them. He had killed too many men, in front of his children's eyes. Their blood had run a river down the path, but in the end, Kane had taken the advantage. Ryan had traded his freedom then, for his family's safety. It hurt more then any physical pain the way his son had looked at his father. There had been fear, understanding, and something else that was unreadable.

"Shalar," he said, opening his eyes. Ryan's will was stronger then ever now, vowing that his son's last vision of his father would not be coated in blood. "I need your help."

There was no parly of words, just a simple fact. He needed help. He needed to get out of the Arena, and Shalar was the only one who would understand that feeling.

Shalar seemed taken aback. "Help? What sort of help?"

"I need to get out of here, as soon as possible. I know of no one else who could understand that."

"Ryan, I do understand, but I too have reasons to escape..."

"Dammmit Shalar!" he exploded. His eyes grew blood red with anger and frustration. "My family is going to die. I'm sorry that your brother is dead, but at least help me get the chance to save those who I care for."

Shalar hesitated, and then answered...
141112212.title: Help or Fight?

Ryan swung at Shalar, who made no move to stop him as the sword's tip drew a honey-colored line across Shalar's left shoulder. Satisfied, he turned and walked towards the far end of the Arena.
"I will. For what he and his father did to my family, he will burn long and slow."
Mirroring Shalar, he turned and walked from the field.

"No, fool, you cannot disqualify him. He blooded Shalar, and while it was not a true fight, it cannot be said the fight was drawn. Ryan is the clear-cut victor." Calarith stared hard at the stout Arena Master.
"Damn you, Calarith. Fine, Ryan walks- this time. I can only hope you kill him when it is your turn to fight."
"I might let him live, just to spite you," the dragon replied, and spread his wings wide. With a powerful, sinuous lunge, he threw himself off his terrace and winged low over the scrub forest outside the Arena.
1411122121.title: Written in Blood

14111221211.content:
"So Shalar surrendered the fight to you?" Sarah asked, swinging her legs over the side of the bed. Ryan sat below her, turning a small dogtag on a gold chain over in his hand. It made small tinkling noises each time it ran into a pile into his open palm.

"Yes," was all he said, staring into something Sarah couldn't see. She frowned, though used to his actions. He was withdrawn, though not unfriendly, and not at all like the person she had remembered from their youth.

When they were younger, Ryan and her brother had been the best of friends. Ryan had always had a darker mood to him, but could make her laugh.
The man she now knew was nothing like that boy. He had been broken again and again until he had nothing left to live for but his wife.

She tried to keep from feeling at that thought. In their youth, she had imagined that he would eventually marry her. After all, it was only she and her brother that he ever spent time with.
But after Mack had died, Ryan had taken off. She assumed that he had joined the war, but knew little about what had happened to him.

And now he no longer spoke to her as openly. He was a battlehardened warrior now, dedicated to the sword and all that it meant. He had magic too, something ancient that she couldn't understand. She could see pain in his eyes sometimes, but other times she saw only the emptiness, which was so much worse.

"I think I need to speak to Shalar." Ryan said suddenly, startling her out of her thoughts.

"Oh." she said, smiling and jumping off of the top bed. "Well, I'm hungry. See you later."

Ryan nodded, caught up in his own thoughts as well. Finally he stood, still holding the dogtag. He had tried to live by the words inscribed on it, not only to honor the memory of a dead friend, but to perhaps find out what it was that he did believe in. The war had been simple in the very basic sense; Kill your enemy, protect your friend.

He walked out into the hall, wondering who it was they would have fighting when the morning came. The fights for the day were over, and he had won both of his. More would come though.

The sounds of voices came from the mess hall, for some of the local pit fighters came as well. He only glanced in, looking for the bladed-warrior. He spotted him easily, sitting at the same table as Ressek and Siph, though he did not speak.

He walked over and nodded.
"Shalar," he said, sitting down opposite of him.

Shalar looked up. "Come to gloat?" he asked wryly.

Ryan managed a small smile. "Not exactly. But if you don't mind..." here he winked.

"So the catalyst has a sense of humor. Wonderful." The jovial mood faded. "So, what is it that you are here about?"

Ryan's smile was gone now, only the sadness again. It was a look most who knew him were familiar with. His gray eyes went out of focus as his closed fist opened. Shalar noticed the sparkle of metal, still bright, though it seemed old.

"Here," Ryan said suddenly, tossing it to the other warrior. "I no longer need the memories this thing holds. Besides, I think you find its words to be wise."

With that said, Ryan left the table. Shalar opened his hand, readin the inscription.
"Tis better to die for what you believe in, than to hide behind what you don't."
14111221211.title: "Tis better..."

141112212112.content:
Ryan was about to leave the room when he was called by one of the Arena guards, who waved him over and spoke gruffly.

"You 'ave a visitor, come with me." He delivered the statement with little joy, and little interest. Ryan nodded, though secretly his heart leapt. Her? Would she...no. She had no idea where he was or even if he were alive. It was better if she didn't. Saying nothing he followed the guard. What was the point of trying to converse with a slovenly beast like this? This part of the arena he had not seen before. The passages were clean of blood, and whitewashed. Probobly a place for offices or some such. The door that was opened was bound with clean, shining iron and was stained cherry. The room beyond was surprising, above ground. A small window was set in the wall, though it was barred. It was dusk outside, and the sun setting.

"You may leave us, sir." The two people in the room stood by the window, cloaked, and by the folds in at their sides, armed. "He is no danger to us." The one talking was obviously a woman, by the voice and skirts.

"er, allright, but if he gives you any trouble, just call." The guard nodded and shut the door behind his exiting, he would not be far off.

"Ryan...Am I right?" The woman let her hood fall, as did her male companion. "Ryan Lee Romarc?" Her face was unfamiliar. Brown hair falling in a braid to her elbow. Green eyes studying him carefuly. She had pale skin, and was pinked by the sun. Of Short stature, though. Her companion was much taller, though bore the same features.

"How do you know my name?" He asked, he was guarded, careful. He had no idea what they wanted.

"Good, then you are who we're looking for." The man sighed and sat at the table in the room. "Do you know how hard you are to track down? It wasn't until we got into the city that we heard jabber about you, the Catalyst they said...could only be-"

"Who sent you?" He asked, cutting him off. The girl looked up at his sun tanned face, traced with little scars.

"Don't get snippy, mister, we were hired to find you by..."
141112212112.title: A Visitation

He tells them to forget they ever saw him
1411122121121.content:
"...Your wife, sent us." The girl replied. "She's payed a good sum of money for us to find you. Though her mother was insistant you were dead."

"Kopri..." He slid down into a chair at the table. "My love...how is she?" He tried to keep emotion from his voice, but it had been so long since he had even heard a word from that area of the world since he entered the arena.

"Alive and well, since we last met her. As well are her...your...children." The man corrected himself. "I can see the resemblance now...the eldest, didn't get his name, looks much like you...same eyes. Quiet though-"

"Oh shut up already, chatterbox, we're not hear to talk about people's kids." The woman snapped. The man fell silent. "My name, if you're wondering is Annie. This is my brother, Mark. We were hired quite by chance to find you and bring you back. Now that we see your predicament I don't know how possible thats going to be."

"I don't know either. The only way to get out of the Arena is by either death or winning." Ryan mused, lost in his thoughts...she shouldn't have sent anyone. It would break her heart to know what he had been forced into. He could not have it.

At the same time she was in danger, and that he could not stand either. She would be safe with her mother, she was powerfull enough to protect Kopri, and their children...for the moment. His enemy would eventually find away around his mother-in-law's protection to his family. He had to get out of here.

"You know, there might be a way to get you out of here..." Mark thought for a moment. "Tell me what you think of this idea..."
1411122121121.title: A word from home

14111221211212.content:
He sat, bewildered for a moment, and then his mind sobered. He got up from his chair, staring out the window. To be free again...Her raven hair spilling over the covers as she slept soundly in his arms, lips twitching in a sweet smile to some sweet dream. The candles burning down as moonlight filled the room, a breeze teasing the curtains.... He snapped out of the reverie and turned his back.

"Go." He snapped.

"What? We just got here, I'm sure we could-" The woman started but he shook his head.

"Get out of here." He commanded, pointing toward the door. "The only way out of the Arena is to win or die. They wouldn't ransom me off. I'm too valuable."

"What are we supposed to tell her? That you decided to stay, to lose hope?" The man tried to reason with the warrior, but he would hear none of it.

"I've lost no hope!" He cried. "I thank you, for letting me know she is well. That gives me more hope still." He knew it was almost useless to hope, but new determination rose in him. He would not give up so soon, not now. He was close, he could beat it. He could win his own freedom. He could have a thousand nights and more with her again.

"Tell her nothing. You did not find me here."

"Then she will surely think you dead! Can we at least tell her you are alive?" The woman watched him with disbelief, thinking wryly that Catherine would not be allowed to be right. He would not die so easily. He would never give in.

"Tell her I am alive, that I will return, but I am held against my will. Tell her nothing whatsoever about the Arena, for my honor." He paused, hoping they would do that for him.

"All right you crazy sonnofabitch, but we'll probably be back." She snorted, reaching into her satchel on the table. "She asked, if ye be well, that you at least write her a note for evidence." She pulled out a piece of parchment, a bottle of ink, and a quill that was broken in half, but would suffice. She pointed to them insistantly and he took his seat once more, staring at the blank page.

What could he write? After all this time...wishing he could speak to her, write to her, have any communication at all...and he could think of barely a word. What could he say? He could promise nothing. He wanted to promise her that he would be home tomorrow, but he couldn't.

"No." He pushed the articles away. "Just tell her I will make it home. Soon. I promise it." He wouldn't let them say anything more to sway his mind. He was almost out of the door when he stopped a moment, saying quietly, eyes downcast though her face flickered before him. "Tell her I still love her."

"Sure, fine, stubborn..." The woman called after him, temper probably egged on by the sunburn and the heat. He sighed. Knowing Kopri, and her mother, he would be seeing those two again. He shouldn't have even spoken to them.

He was brought back to the common room, though many people had gone for an early bit of shuteye, but he resumed a seat in the corner, mulling it over. Could they keep his whereabouts a secret? How long would it be before Kopri got it in her head to come looking for him herself? No. Her mother could hold her back, and she would never leave the children.

He sighed, leaning his head against the wall. Another day, another fight, another scar, another day closer to release.
14111221211212.title: Bitter Refusal

"Even though I am Harac's grandson?" he asked quietly. Shalar seemed startled. He may have known that in some way Ryan was related to the dead wizard, but he didn't know that he would be so frank.

knew it was better than his whole body
catching on fire.

When the burning stopped, Resseck tore his
arms away and looked up.
152111.title: Fire Ball

choices: Resseck decides to do the attacking now.
1521112.content:
Raven's spot in the sky was empty. Desperate
to get a contact, Resseck snapped his head in
all directions. Where had he gone? Where
was he? Resseck started to get panicky. If
he didn't know where his opponent was, it
could be his very death.

A click from behind him made Resseck turn and
move to the right. But, it was a little to
late. One of Raven's mighty claws ripped a
tear straight across Resseck's belly.
Resseck grabbed his stomach with one hand and
propped himself up in a very lizard like
stance with the other. He let out a scream
that was more like a combination between and
hiss and a roar. If the claw had gone any
deeper, his insides would be out on the arena
right now. He had to be more cautious.

Resseck climbed back to his feet and faced
Raven. It was time to end this fight, or
else die trying. "You came close that time,
but it won't happen again." Resseck hissed at
Raven.

Raven's beak turned into an ugly smile.
Resseck wanted to run, he wanted to forfiet.
Raven's smile was so evil, so turthful. He
knew that if he lost this battle, Raven would
devour him. That wasn't a fate he wanted to
have.
1521112.title: Not My Fate

152112.content:
Resseck tried to get out of the way, but
Raven's sharp talons came down into his arms,
pinning him to the ground. Raven's teeth
sank deep into Resseck's stomach. Resseck
screamed out in pain as Raven tore away a
chunk of flesh. Resseck had never been in so
much pain in his entire life time. He
screamed as he felt Raven's hot breath on his
face and his own blood dripping from Raven's
fangs onto his forehead.

Resseck could only faintly hear Siph
screaming from the crowd. The crowd, that's
what was odd. There was no cheering. No one
cheered as the dragonite chewed on Resseck's
flesh. Resseck felt blood come up his throat.

There was a loud scream as people tried to
restrain Siph from jumping into the arena.
Raven's attention was distracted for a
second. Resseck's energy was completely
gone. But, did he have enough to use Raven's
distraction as an advantage? Could he summon
enough strength to break free and try to
escape with his life?
152112.title: Under Teeth

choices: Resseck wakes up in the med center.
Resseck wakes up, still on the field with Siph by him.
1521121.content:
The memory of the conversation with Siph
before the fight came flooding back into
Resseck's mind. He couldn't leave Siph to
fight on his own in the Arena, Siph would
surely die. He couldn't let Raven get to
Siph, or the other opponents. There was no
way. None of them would be able to beat the
dragonite.

Resseck tensed his muscles and then shot out
his feet. His razor sharp claws connected
with Raven's jaw, piercing through the scaley
skin and coming out the top of Raven's head.
The dragonite's body slumped down onto
Resseck and was completely limp. Resseck
pushed it off of him and looked down at the
dragonite. Blood came from every inch of the
dragonite's head. Resseck's claws had gone
straight through Raven's brain, shattering
the skull. Even if Raven had survived, his
brain would be mush, and the dragonite
wouldn't live for a day or so. But, luckily
for the dragonite, the blow had killed him.

Resseck climbed to his feet and the crowd
cheered. Resseck heard Siph laughing and
cheering along with them. The Arena Master,
a little surprised that the battle was over
so quickly, raised a yellow flag, announcing
Resseck's victory.

Resseck couldn't take his eyes off of the
young dragonite. He knew that Raven would
have killed him, but still, he felt bad for
having to kill Raven. Why had he ever joined
the arena fights? They were awful.

Suddenly, a wave of nausea and weakness hit
Resseck. His vision went blurry and he felt
his knees buckle. His hands went to his
stomach, and he realized why. Raven had
taken a bite out of him, that's why. He was
missing part of the flesh on his stomach.
Blood oozed out all over his legs and stomach.

Resseck fell to the ground in a heap of
exhaustion and blood. He breathed heavily
and for the first time, the pain struck him
hard. He cried out and soon, darkness took
him over.
1521121.title: Darkness

15211212.content:
Resseck opened his eyes and found the dark
orange outline of Siph looking down at him.
He could feel the sand beneath him, he was
still out in the arena. "Rethik? Rethik,
you're gonna be okay." Siph cooed softly.
"Medicth are on their way. Pleathe don't
die." Siph started crying.

Resseck gurlged on blood as a few of the
arena's guards came out to help carry Resseck
off the field. Before Resseck could protest,
he felt hands under his arms and feet and
then he was lifted off the ground. He
cringed in pain and growled. "Be careful
with him!" Siph yelled, following them closely.

Resseck was carried off into the bunks. The
large stone doors closed Siph off in the
arena to fight his fight. Resseck just hoped
the two of them would see each other again.
15211212.title: Siph's Plea

choices: Resseck tells Sarah he is going to forfeit.
Resseck tells Sarah he will give her a good fight.
152112121.content:
Resseck lay on the bunk, a large cloth over
his stomach. He had been hurt bad, he knew
that. But, the guards had told him that the
Arena Master had declared him the victor
before he fell, so he would have to fight
again. Resseck just hoped that whoever he
fought wasn't out to kill him because he knew
he would not be able to win his next fight.

The door to the bunk squeaked open and
Resseck turned his head to look at who had
come in. To his surprise, it was a female
human. He recognized her as Sarah, Ryan's
friend. Resseck had a certain respect for
Ryan, he could connect with him. And so, he
didn't fear Sarah. Resseck growled as a wave
of pain shot through him.

"Resseck?" Came Sarah's soft voice.

Resseck nodded and turned back to her. "Why
have you come here?" He asked, trying to
sound stronger than he really was.

"I came here because your next fight is
against me." Sarah said, closing the door
behind her. She walked over to the bed.
Resseck pondered her words. If they were
fighting next, why was she in here talking to
him? Sarah kneeled down next to the bed.
"Resseck, I respect you. It took a lot of
strength and self control to beat Raven like
that." Sarah said.

Resseck chuckled and looked away. "Raven,
that young dragon is going to haunt me
forever." Resseck said, his mind flashing
back to the blood that had seeped from
Raven's crushed skull.

"Why? You won." Sarah said.

Resseck turned back. He looked into Sarah's
eyes. Sarah was human, Resseck admired that.
Although he was reptilian, he had always
admired the make of humans. How could they
walk with no tail and such small feet? It
was always a question he asked himself.
"There are things you have to learn about
winning. No one won that fight today."
Resseck said.

"What do you mean? You killed Raven, you
won." Sarah insisted.

Resseck chuckled again. "No. I killed
Raven, but I did not win. Killing and
winning are two different things. It was an
unfair fight."

"Unfair! Maybe for you, but Raven could have
killed you out there."

"I know, but there was a distraction in our..."

"Resseck," Sarah leaned forward and took
Resseck's hand in her own. Resseck enjoyed
her touch. It was gentle and soft, something
he hadn't felt in a while. "A true fighter
does not become distracted. The fight was
unfair to you, but you still won."

"I killed Raven, I did not win. If anyone
won that fight, it would be Raven."

"What are you talking about Resseck?"

"It was not my choice to join the arena
fights. I don't want to fight, I hate it.
But, if I do not, I will be stuck here
forever, and Siph will probably be killed as
well. I have to fight, and when I am forced
to fight, I do not win."

Sarah thought about it for a moment. "I
think I see what you're saying. There's more
to winning than just coming out on the top of
a fight."

Resseck curled his reptilian lips, "Yes." He
said and closed his eyes as another wave of
pain struck him. Sarah watched the reptile
for a moment longer. Then she stood.

"Resseck, I am your next opponent, and I
promise you, I will not kill you."

Resseck looked up at her. "But, if you do
not win..."

"I have no one to go home to." Sarah said.
"My entire family was killed. You deserve to
go on, not me."

Resseck sighed. Did he really want to go on?
Or did he want to give this girl a chance to
get out alive.
152112121.title: Sarah

1521121212.content:
"Very well, Sarah. I promise not to kill you either. With luck you will make your way back up in future victories." Ressek coughed, a trickle of blood leaking from the bandage around his midsection. He sighed in annoyance, and held out his long fingers to Sarah, who took them carefully in her own hand and shook with him. The bargain was done.

The next day dawned bright and clear. Ressek was healed physically, thanks to the magic of the Arena's healers, but he could still feel the aching pain of the wound, which would last for a very long time, possibly forever. Damn you, Raven. Damn you to hell. Across from him, he could make out Sarah just entering. The dust blown around the bowl of the Arena bit into his tender stomach, furthering the pains beneath his gravelly skin. Ressek winced. This is going to be a long fight indeed...
1521121212.title: Bargained Well, and Done

15211212121.content:
Sarah approached him, giving him a wink. "Not all rigged events are thanks to that podgy 'Arena master'," she whispered.
"And for that, I am thankful." Ressek winced- perahaps his injuries were even worse than he thought.

The red cloth dropped. An expectant hush came over the crowd.

Ressek struck first, using the flat of his long-fingered hands to shove Sarah backwards. But as she fell, she seemed to melt into the ground. In seconds, she had disappeared, the puff of dust the only marking that she had even hit the ground. Shadow blood! Dammit, I forgot!
"You're not going to make it that easy, I see," Ressek whispered, afraid that the Arena master would overhear him and figure out what was happening.
"Why should I? I want this to look real," a voice whispered at his back. Quick as lightining, he spun, whipping out his tail. He felt one of his bony nodules connect with something, and Sarah's form appeared out of nowhere, flung on her back and gasping for air. Damn, I hit her hard! But I can't help her, either! Damn it all!
But he worried needlessly- moments later, she was on her feet, tossing a long thin dagger between her hands.
"If you don't pull punches, I won't either."
"You wanted it to look real," Ressek replied, and readied himself for an attack.
15211212121.title: Mock Battle

152112121211.content: As Sarah circled, however, Ressek got the opening he wanted. Despite Raven having taken a chunk of him in his earlier fight, Ressek was still a capable fighter. He lashed out with one long leg, kicking Sarah onto her back again. This time she did not melt away as she had earlier, but rolled with the kick, reversing the somersault to land unsteadily on her feet. Dusty, but mostly unhurt, she flicked the dagger at Ressek. He only just missed getting skewered, as the dagger shot past him and buried itself in a chink in the stone wall, several paces behind him. A tiny slice along his ribs showed how close the miss had been, however. With blows exchanged, Sarah and Ressek settled back into circling, Ressek wondering why they were going to such lengths for a rigged fight, and why it couldn't appear rigged in the first place...
152112121211.title: Tail for Knife

1521121212111.content:
Ressek had no time to wonder about this, however, as Sarah lunged for him again, her dagger flashing brightly. Quick as lightning, Ressek spun, bringing the thick ankle of his right leg into Sarah's back. The hit was light, but Sarah sprawled forward, dust rising and settling again as she lay there, still.
"Sarah..?" Ressek asked, haltingly. As he watched, blood spread out around her head, turning the dirt a wet, dark brown. Ressek wondered belatedly if she had fallen on her knife in some way. "Sarah?" he asked again.
1521121212111.title: Blood

choices: A break before Ressek's next fight
15211212121111.content:
Bending down near her, he rolled her on her side. "Sarah, are you alright?" Ressek asked.
"I'm fine," she hissed, surprising him. "I drew a small cut on my forehead. I'll be fine. Signal the healers, let the fight end. You've won."
Quickly, Ressek did as she asked, still doubting the faked ending she had given him. However, as the healer mages drew closer, Ressek knew the fight was over. Their drama had been played out, and he, Ressek, had emerged the winner.

"So, you let yourself fall, cut yourself on purpose, and let Ressek win? Why, Sarah?" Ryan stared at her in disbelief.
"He needs to survive, to win this tournament. The Arena master has rigged these fights somehow, and winning doesn't matter nearly as much as seeing innocents like Ressek survive. Like Shalar, the Arena master wants him dead. Shalar can take care of himself, I believe, but Ressek is in over his head, and against his will. You know all too well what that's like."
"You are a better person that I, Sarah."
"No," she interrupted him, "just better than you were. Your goals are more noble than most of those here. Saving someone's life is always a worthy cause, as long as that person's life is worthy."
Silence hung heavy in the room. Quietly, Ryan put his arms around Sarah, hugging her. Wishing once again that he could see his family.
Sarah rested her chin on her friend's shoulder, returning the hug. Wishing she had a family...
15211212121111.title: False Ending

152112121211111.content:
Ressek had a chance to rest and watch the fight between Marr and Elise. He hated the fight and often looked away, at the other arena fighters who were sitting watching. Siph sat next to him, solely worried. Siph had won his first fight against Tyger. It had been a brutal fight, Ressek had heard it all from Siph who still carried a wound to his right eye that kept it closed.

The fight going on now was the first fight for both Marr and Elise. Their fight had been postponed due to a trick played by Marr to try and escape. But they had found him and he was forced to fight.

Ressek watched Elise use magic to try and freeze the bog wraith, but nothing was working. Marr kept on lashing at Elise, causing a new deep scratch every time he did. Ressek leaned back, closing his eyes.

"Rethik, watch thith." Siph said, intrigued by the fight. Ressek opened his eyes and watched as Marr consumed Elise. Her screams echoed through out the arena and when the wraith had moved past her, all that was left was a pile of bones. The mage had been brought down to nothing but bones.

"That's horrible." Ressek whispered.

Siph turned to him and Ressek looked into Siph's orange eyes. "You okay Rethik?" He asked.

Ressek nodded. "I hate the fighting Siph." Ressek said, rubbing his reptilian eyes.

Siph curled his mouth. "I know Rethik. I'm thorry for making you come." Siph looked hurt and Ressek perked up.

"Siph, who is your next fight against?" Ressek asked, trying to change the subject.

Siph smiled. "Ryan."

Ressek sank again. He didn't know who was going to win Siph's next fight. He didn't want to think about it. He loved Siph for a friend and didn't want to see him trapped away in this arena forever. But he also respected Ryan so much and knew that Ryan wasn't fighting for himself. Ressek noticed Siph's questioning look and smiled at him. "Good luck Siph. You'll need it."

"Nah, I'll beat that human. You'll thee Rethik. I'll beat him good." Ressek only hoped that Siph wouldn't get himself killed.
152112121211111.title: Talking with Siph

15211212121112.content:
Sarah lay on a stiff medic's pallet, scowling at the ceiling. "Hello, Ressek," she said as the reptillian martial artist walked in. The surprise on his face made his former opponent grin.
"I'm just fine, in case you're wondering. Those damn medics insist I have to stay here for another hour, just to make sure."
"I don't see a cut on you, anywhere," Ressek said, confused.
Sarah held up her hand, showing a bandage over the top of her hand. "I cut myself on purpose, to end the fight. Like I said, I'm fine. Now go, get ready for your next fight. I guarentee it will be painful and hard, no matter what that podgy bastard throws at you." She stared at him, a fire in her eyes. "Beat him, Ressek. Beat everyone, win the tournament. Defeat Calarith." She chuckled. "Piss off that goddamn Arena master."
Ressek laughed, a fire starting to burn in his own heart as well. "Take care, Sarah. Survive your fights as well- I'll see you when this is all over. When the Arena master is crying like an infant because I beat his odds."
The fight had returned to Ressek's soul. It was more than just watching out for Siph, now. It was for his own survival, and he'd be damned if he made it easy for them.
15211212121112.title: Infirmary Confession

choices: "Siph was my friend, I will not let his murderer live."
"No.  Krath must pay, and he will do so in fighting Calarith."
152112122.content:
Resseck woke up to the sounds of cheering.
He turned his head slightly to look out of
his door. Krath stood in the hallway, being
praised by Marr and the Arena Master. "Thank
you, thank you. Now we know who is the best
fighter here." Krath said and laughed
heartily. They three of them talked away and
Resseck sat up. He swung his legs off the
bed. How had he healed so fast? The large
chunk of missing flesh was now nothing more
than a scar.

Resseck stood up and his answer caught him
square in the face. A note was dangling from
the ceiling. It was from Elise. "You won a
fight for me today. I will repay you."

Resseck touched his stomach. He mouthed the
words, "Thank you."

Outside, he saw the clawy form of Shalar pass
by his door. He hurried out and caught
Shalar by the arm, being careful not to slice
his hand on one of Shalar's many blades.
"Shalar."

Shalar turned and looked Resseck in the face.
"Krath, who did he beat?" Resseck asked.

Shalar's shoulders drooped. He sighed and
said, "Resseck, Krath's fight was against Siph."

A wave of panic ran through Resseck. "Siph?
Where is he?"

Shalar frowned. "He fought bravely Resseck.
Siph just...he just wasn't strong enough for
Krath."

Resseck suddenly felt weak. His entire
reason for fighting in the arena fights had
just been killed. His best friend, the one
he aimed to protect, his only means of
inspiration, dead? Resseck felt his
reptilian eyes fill with tears and he fell to
his knees. Shalar squatted in front of him.
"Resseck, don't give up." Shalar looked
around like he wasn't suppose to be talking
to Resseck. "The whole thing was planned."

"What?" Resseck growled at him.

Shalar shook Resseck gently. "Don't blame
me. I had nothing to do with it. No one
else knows that I know, so I don't want you
telling anyone that it was I who told you.
Resseck, you are going to face Calarith and
you are going to die, it's in the arena
masters plan."

"Calarith? Die? Why do they want me to do
that? I never did anything to them." Resseck
started sobbing.

Shalar shook him again. "Resseck, damnit
listen! There is a way to beat this. Your
next fight is against Krath, and you are
scheduled to win this one. Krath is not
going to fight you with his full power. But,
they made one mistake along the way. Krath
has won all his battles so far, which is more
than the rest of us. If he wins to you, then
he will have to fight Calarith. That's not
part of their plan. If he fights, he will
lose. Don't you see? You have to lose your
fight against Krath."

"But...but Krath killed Siph."

Shalar rolled his black eyes. "Resseck, is
vengence more important to you than life?"

Resseck thought. Then he said...
152112122.title: Vengence or Life?

choices: "I will fight you in the arena."
1521121221.content:
Ressek stood up, gathering himself. "If I purposely lose the battle against Krath, then he will face Calarith?"

"Yes." Shalar said, also standing up. Ressek looked sideways and then back at Shalar. Ressek trusted Shalar, but thought that he had no sense of honor and justice. He didn't know Shalar that well, but maybe he just thought that because he would not die to avenge a friend.

"Shalar, if Krath beats me and goes to fight Calarith, there is always the chance that he may pull a miracle and beat Calarith. Then he will win the arena fights and leave with pride. I can't let that happen. He must fall by my hand and no other."

"But Ressek, you are not powerful enough to beat Calarith." Shalar said.

"There is one more fight before I fight Calarith Shalar. I do not plan on wining that fight." Ressek said.

Shalar tilted his head. "Which fight?"
1521121221.title: Honor a Friend

15212.content:
Raven ran around again, cocky because he had hit Resseck. But, Resseck wasn't going to let that happen again.

Raven came in for the kill. Resseck suddenly lept up, and Raven ran right under him. A little confused, Raven slowed down, which gave Resseck the advantage. Resseck came down on top of him and sunk his claws deep into Raven's tough black skin. Raven cried and the crowd cheered.

Resseck jumped off. No, this wasn't suppose to happen. Why was the crowd cheering? Because he almost killed someone? What a cruel world, Resseck turned to look at the wounded Raven. Raven swayed a little, but then turned around, his face growling with anger.

Resseck felt that deep down, one of them was going to die in this fight, and it wasn't going to be him.
15212.title: Resseck Hits Raven

choices: Resseck stays in his peaceful world.
152121.content:
Raven charged again and Resseck pivoted out
of the way. Memories of home came flooding
back into Resseck's mind. No! He had to
stay focused! Why were all these stupid
feelings rushing in on him now? He had to
win this fight. Siph was counting on him.

Raven lashed around with one of his mightly
clawed limbs. Four claws slashed into
Resseck's side, dark red blood eminating from
the shiny black skin on Resseck's body.
Resseck didn't even yelp.

What was going on? Why couldn't he
concentrate on the fight? Raven stopped
moving and looked into Resseck's eyes.
Raven's face scrunched and he spat, "Resseck,
you fighting or shall I just kill you?"

Resseck started breathing heavily. What was
happening? What were these flashbacks.
Then, suddenly, the fight was gone. The
arena walls were no more. The spectators
were gone. Resseck was back at home, with
Siph by his side. Everything was peaceful,
like it used to be. Everything was calm,
there was no Raven.

Meanwhile, back in the arena, Raven circled
around Resseck's body. Resseck had fallen to
the ground, Raven thought it was a trick. He
couldn't have beaten Resseck so easily.
There was no way. Raven inched closer and
poked Resseck with his tail. He scurried
away, but when Resseck didn't even flinch he
stood on his hind legs. "I won!" He screeched.

The arena master sitting at the highest point
stood up. He was about to call the victory.
Resseck smelt blood. There, in his peaceful
world, was the acrid stench of blood.
What the hell is going on? Resseck
tried to scream out, but he coulnd't hear
himself. He only thought it.

Suddenly, Siph's voice came to his mind.
"Resseck, it's the mage woman, she's trying
to make you lose. She wants to fight Raven,
so she's blocking you from fighting. You
have to get up Resseck. They'll kill you if
you don't. I heard them talking, please
Resseck. Get up!"

Siph had always had a little knack of knowing
how to communicate through telpathy. Resseck
thought it over. Was it right to give up his
peaceful world to just win a fight? No,
there was more to it. He had to go back to
the fight, Siph was counting on him.
152121.title: Mage Magic

153.content:
Marr floated silently at the center of the Arena, eyes-to-face with David. The werewolf would be trouble, but Marr was not afraid. With sickle and claws the only solid part of him, he knew it was a very long chance that David would hit his one weak point, his glowing red eyes. He has no hope, a mere creature of flesh.
The Arena master was anxious to get the fight started, and quickly announced the grandeur of the Arena and its fights before dropping the red cloth he held.
As it fluttered to the ground, the fight was joined.
153.title: Marr's First Fight

choices: David waits, and attacks into Raven
154.content:
David stared at the roster for a moment. First fight was with him, and Raven. He had not yet seen the dragonette, but had heard of his violence. He could inflict a lot of damage on a person for such a small dragon, and was very quick. But David had some advantages of his own.

He turned and headed down the hall towards the Arena entrance. An Arena orderly waited at the entrance. "You're up in a moment." he told the lycanthrope, and David nodded.
A sudden roar filled the Arena, shaking David right to his bones. Glancing out into the dusty bowl, he could see the great dragon Calarith perched on a large platform, breathing fire and a challenge to the sky.

David took a breath as the Arena Master began to announce his first fight, and then he strode out into the bright morning light, prepared to fight for his freedom.

At that time, Raven was released, and the dragonette swept out of its cage with blood lust in his eyes. David drew his sword and prepared for the attack.
154.title: David's First Fight

choices: He uses his magic to turn into a wolf
1541.content:
David stood his ground as the red-scaled dragonette barreled out at him. He waited, knowing that if he timed this wrong, it would most likely end badly for him. Closer...closer...

Suddenly he dodged Raven and brought his sword down towards the dragonette's head. Raven howled, seeing it just in time. He leaped to the side, but couldn't dodge it completely and the sword grazed his stomach. He made an odd throaty noise, that sounded almost like a laugh, and threw himself after David. The lycanthrope dodged, as if in a dance with Raven. They were moving together now, making it difficult for one to gain the advantage.

Suddenly Raven began to run to the left, but at the last second he swerved to the right and threw himself at David. The lycanthrope had been thrown off by the feint and was hit head on by the dragonette. Raven crowed in delight as David struggled to keep him at bay. It can't end like this. By the Gods, please not like this... He thought desperately.

David brought the pommel of his sword around and smacked Raven's head. The dragonette growled but would not get off. David had one hand at his throat, and with the other he continued to beat Raven with his sword.
1541.title: A Beating

15411.content:
Raven snapped and clawed at David as they struggled on the Arena's floor. The dragonette's claws raked bloody furrows down David's chest as it struggled to get at him. With a final, mighty effort, David brought every ounce of strength he had into another pommel blow. With a traumatized squeak, Raven released his hold on the lycanthrope and rolled away. Shaking the dust off his black scales, Raven stood, watching David rise to his feet, his sword leveled at the dragonette. Predator's instincts ran through the veins of both combatants, and an instant later, they were at each other again. David slashed low with his sword, but the dragonette leapt above the blade. It snapped at David as it came to eye level, but Talis again brought the pommel of his sword up, smashing Raven in the jaw. The dragonette chirped and threw itself at David, who sidestepped and slashed him along the flank. Dragon's blood splashed the ground.
Angry and frustrated, the dragonette spun on David, but the human kept his head clear, and ducked under the leaping dragonette. His sword drew another slash in Raven's black scales, and he landed painfully behind David. Not one to give up, Raven leapt again.
Enough of this. I'll be picking him apart all day. As the little dragon left the ground, David sidestepped again. Already in the air, his wings too weak to use, Raven chirped angrily.
Talis grabbed Raven's left arm, and the dragon seemed to curl up at him, trying to reach David with his legs and teeth, but the effort was wasted.
Pivoting, David threw Raven bodily towards the wall, using every shred of strength he could find. The thrashing dragon struck the Arena's wall and slumped to the ground.
15411.title: Flying Dragonette

155.content:
Johnathan walked down the length of the hall, spotting his father leaning against the side. He had a worried look about him, and John wondered what it was. He walked up to him, giving his father a quizical look.
"What's wrong?"
"You're up first." David said quietly. John gave him a smile.
"Don't worry. I'll do fine. Who's it against, anyway?"
David hesitated, then tilted his head towards the roster. "Check it out."

Johnathon walked over to the roster worried. It wasn't like his father to act this way unless it was really bad. Either he was fighting David, or he was just fighting someone really hard.
His eyes scanned the paper quickly and paused when he saw his name. With a sigh he turned to the entrance and waited for his name to be called.
155.title: Johnathan's First Fight

1551.content:
Johnathan had known, undeniably, that this time would come. He steeled himself against the aching pain that threatened to shatter his soul. What would he become, in the ring, to murder his own father? He imagined an image of himself as a wolf, a mirror of the creature his father was. He imagined both of them circling in the ring, teeth gnashing, huge bodies twisting in a dance of raw and bloody death. He told himself that he would not fight but he knew that he would, once he had changed he became the thing he had changed into completely. There was simply no Johnathan left. If he turned into a dragon then it would be with that dragon's lust for blood that he tore into his father.

He shuddered at the thought. To have come all this way just to mangle the man he was trying so desperately to save, or be mangled by him. It was a thought to terrible to bear. His mother's face swam on the edges of his mind, her wide blue eyes begging him not to answer the bell that was tolling in the stands above, not to heed the call to the arena battle. In the shadows of his mind he turned away from her. I'm sorry, his soul called. He knew both he and his father lacked the discipline necessary simply NOT to kill each other in battle. In their very being lay an uncontrolled sympathy with the creatures that they became. There was no mind in the monsters that sprouted forth from their bodies, only the mindless urge to to be whatever it was that they were and completely.

His father could no more deny the bloodlust of the wolf than Johnathan could control whatever thing sprouted from him on the wings of his rage and fear at the prospect of battle. Whatever he became, whatever manner of winged and fanged beast his body deemed necessary to win the battle ahead, he would fight to the death and with no remorse.

The bell called again, drawing him toward the fight. Already his body was churning in answer to the call of blood so readily offered. He looked at the weapons pooled for those who did not bring their own and chose a blunt stick. It wouldn't matter what manner of weapon he carried into battle. He would never use it. His body would change and he would sprout whatever manner of weapon, claw, fang, tentacle, it deemed necessary to survive.

He strode toward the light of the doorway that would lead to the battle ahead. His body smelled the blood from previous battles and his cells did a dark and happy dance that called for a swift change in form. His body began to feel less and less his own as he stepped into the golden ligh of the arena and his feet swept across the floor made of golden sand and sawdust.

His father was on the other side. Even from across the arena Johnathan could see the shadow of the wolf in his eyes.

" You should not have come!" David howled miserably, his voice was already deep with the change. The wolf was coming, unbidden and his father was helpless to fight the beast when the smell of blood and death was so ripe and rampant in the air.

Johnathan felt his own body changing. Dark hair sprouted from his body. His worst nightmare had come true. He would meet his father, wolf to wolf on the battle field. Those that had paid their well earned coin to view the battles in the arena today were going to get their money's worth. The carnage would be legendary, made worse by the fact that those watching knew that the battle was between father and son.

In the few moments where Johnathan was still himself he heard his mother scream his name. Then she was gone, along with the rest of his mind. A terrible pain roared through him as his version of the wolf came, in the distance he could see his father, bathed in the unnatural sunlight that he loathed, as did all creatures who bore wolf's blood. The unnatural change, the day change was well upon him and the beast within would be all the more fierce for having to face the sun.

Johnathan, the thing he was becoming anyway, felt the horrible agony of his bones breaking in his legs, turning backwards and then binding again. He screamed. The crowd in the arena howled in pleasure as the two combatants writhed on the ground in dark agony.

The thing that stood up in Johnathan's place was covered in a thick matting of darkly silver fur. It had a ebony streak on its broad back. It was well over nine feet tall on two legs, and it had large, yellowed fangs coming from its wide and snapping jaws.

The other monster wolf was inky black with slitted golden eyes that watched the creature standing across from it with a cruel and calculating intelligence born of its disconnected human brain. The David wolf was ten feet tall, broader than its oponnent, with long inky black claws ready to rip and tear into silver fur and the flesh beneath.

The came at each other on all fours and met in the middle of the blood splattered, saw dust covered arena. The Johnathan creature threw its head back and howled as the David thing tore at it with inky claws. Blood flew from the wounds in Johnathan's silver chest. He backed away and came at his father again, enraged.

Older and wiser the David thing watched the pup coming and turned suddenly, so that Johnathan passed him. David reached behind him with sharp claws and tore much of the fur and skin from the pups back.

Johnathan the wolf howled in agony. He whirled on his opponent quickly and tore at the other creatures throat with his sharp yellow jaws. He had a hold but the black on fought furiously, pain came from everywhere, as the creature tore into every part of him that was availabe and sought to rip him open in several place. Johnathan did not let go, he snapped harder until he had what he wanted the most. The creatures pulse beat strong beneath his teeth.

He had only to bite down to end this, and feast upon the warm blood and flesh beneath the skin.

High above, in the stands, nestled in the treasured place created only for the wealthy or politically important Calirath watched, his golden eyes mad with the desire to join the beautiful crimson fray playing out on the ground below him.

He smiled with sharp, golden fangs. The pup thinks he's won, Calirath thought, amused, but the older one, he's crafty, going for the heart . . .

The dragon wondered what it would be like to face the two of them at the same time, visions of blood danced like raw meat in his eager brain. A blood bath, he thought, envisioning his hard fought and well one victory. His smile widened as the silver wolf yelped, just now beginning to feel sharp claws digging into the the fleshy cage of meat and bone that protected his heart.

" Well fought young one," Calirath whispered to himself, " but now it is time to die."

Johnathan howled in agony and bit down on David's neck hard enough for sweet and salty blood to flow into his waiting jaws. He tried to shake himself free of the other's grasp and save his heart from being ripped free of his body.

The wolves stilled in the arena, each one held the power to kill the other instanly, the crowed drew back in silent awe, watching, waiting . . .

They . . .

Ideas conceived by both .Wolfie. (105) , nephthys, & ΚΙΣVΣ (71) This is the complete version of the original Arena, with a lot more characters, and a lot more action, hopefully.

Complete Character Cast:
Ryan Lee Romarc: Still the best swordsman there is. He is trying to win his freedom in order to return to his family before they are murdered by the man who put him in the Arena. While here, he is known as Michael Ryan, for his own safety.
Siph: A fun little demon, who is in the Arena to be the Champion. He is quick, dangerous, with an almost mischievous look, and deadly horns.
David Talis: David is a werewolf who was enslaved and put to fight in the Arena just after an eighteen year war. Now he only wishes to escape and return home for a well-earned respite.
Johnathan Talis: John is David's son, who ended up in the Arena when he was looking for his father, ironically enough. Now he is fighting to earn them their freedom. He is a changling.
Raven: Raven is a small dragonette. Though not as powerful as a full-grown Dragon, he is still powerful enough. He is in the Arena of his own choice, for he loves the blood.
Elise: Elise is a mage, in the Arena to prove herself and to kill Raven, who she has sworn revenge upon. Her most powerful attack that she favors is a deadly black fireball, which burns the soul.
Tyger: She is a gargoyle, in the Arena for the challenge. She lives to fight, and does so fiercely, using her tail and twin dirks as weapons. She carries a grudge against Ryan for her own reasons.
Ressek: He is a saurian martial artist. He originally came to the Arena to stop his friend, Siph, from joining, but was conscripted.
Krath: Large and stupid are most used to describe this huge monstrosity. He is from a desert in the Southlands and uses his many blades to fight. He is in the Arena as another slave.
Marr: Captured during the same eighteen year war as David, when he slew an entire company of the enemy's troops. He is a bog wraith from a swamp at the foot of the Dragon Mountains.
Sarah Nicolshki: Sarah was the sister of one of Ryan's friends at an early age. She is a thief, a warrior, with Shadow blood in her. This sometimes makes her very difficult to see.
Shalar: Shalar is in the Arena to avenge his brother, Reivus, who was killed by Harac's troops during the eighteen year war. His long, hooked blades reach from almost every joint in his body.
Calarith: This Dragon is the current champion of the Arena. He is the final opponent, if they survive...


Good luck and enjoy.
